{{Infobox military conflict | conflict = Bombardment of Algiers, 1683 | image = Duquesne fait liberer des captifs chretiens apres le bombardement d Alger en 1683.jpg | caption = Augustin Burdet, ''Duquesne liberating the captives after the bombardment of Algiers in 1683'', engraving after [[François-Auguste Biard]]. | partof = Franco-Algerian War (1681-88) | date = June-July 1683 | place = Algiers | coordinates = | map_type = | map_relief = | latitude = | longitude = | map_size = | map_marksize = | map_caption = | map_label = | territory = none | result = liberation of French captives held by Algiers | status = | combatants_header = | combatant1 = [[File:Royal Standard of the King of France.svg|22px|Royal Standard of the King of France]] [[France]] | combatant2 = [[File:Flag of the Ottoman Empire (1453-1844).svg|22px]] [[Ottoman Algiers|Regency of Algiers]] | commander1 = [[Abraham Duquesne]] | commander2 = Baba Hassan, Hadji-Hassein | units1 = 17 [[ships of the line]]
3 [[frigates]]
16 [[galleys]]
7 [[galiot|bomb galiots]]
48 [[longboats]]
18 [[fluyt]]s
8 [[tartans]] | units2 = unknown | strength1 = | strength2 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | notes = | campaignbox = }} The '''bombardment of Algiers''' in 1683 was a French naval operation against the [[Ottoman Algeria|Regency of Algiers]] during the Franco-Algerian War of 1681-88. It led to the rescue of more than 100 French prisoners,{{cite book|author=Clement Melchior Justin Maxime Fourcheux de Montrond|title=Les marins les plus celebres. Par ---. 5. ed|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bSxniTA01v0C&pg=PA55|year=1860|publisher=Lefort|pages=55}} in some cases after decades of captivity, but the great majority of Christian slaves in Algiers were not liberated. == Background == The previous year, [[Louis XIV]] had ordered [[Abraham Duquesne|Duquesne]] to [[Bombardment of Algiers (1682)|bombard Algiers]] after the Dey declared war on France. At the head of a forty-strong fleet, Duquesne sailed to Algiers in July 1682, but bad weather delayed his attack. After several bombardments in August, the city suffered serious damage, but bad weather prevented the signing of a conclusive peace agreement, forcing Duquesne to return to France. In the Spring of 1683, Duquesne set to sea once again with a fleet of 17 [[ships of the line]], 3 [[frigates]], 16 [[galleys]], 7 [[galiot|bomb galiots]], 48 longboats, 18 [[fluyt]]s and 8 [[tartane]]s. This was a larger force than had been sent to Algiers the previous year. As well as being more numerous, the galiots were better equipped and manned by a special corps of bombardiers.{{cite web |url=http://www.vallee-du-ciron.com/Documents/Ouvrages/Michelant/1683.Alger.htm|title=Bombardement d'Alger par Duquesne|last=Michelant |first=L. |date= |website=Faits mémorables de l'histoire de France |publisher= |access-date=21 April 2018 |quote=}} The fleet set sail from [[Toulon]] on 23 May. == Second bombardment of Algiers == The bombardment began on the night of 26-27 June, and two hundred and twenty two bombs, launched in less than twenty four hours, started fires in Algiers and prompted general disorder as well as killing around 300 Algerians. Hassan Dey intended to resist nonetheless, but the population urged him to sue for peace. Duquesne agreed to a truce on condition that all Christian slaves were delivered to him. When the truce expired, Hassan Dey asked for, and received, an extension. Duquesne meanwhile set out his terms for agreeing a peace: * freeing all Christian slaves * an indemnity equal to the value of all the goods seized from France by pirates * a solemn embassy to be sent to Louis XIV to ask his forgiveness for the hostile acts committed against his navy. These terms resolved the Dey to continue resistance.{{cite web |url=http://www.vallee-du-ciron.com/Documents/Ouvrages/Michelant/1683.Alger.htm|title=Bombardement d'Alger par Duquesne|last=Michelant |first=L. |date= |website=Faits mémorables de l'histoire de France |publisher= |access-date=21 April 2018 |quote=}} [[File:Supplice du consul de france pere levacher.JPG|left|thumb|Dutch engraving showing the death of Consul le Vacher, 1698]] One of the Algerian commanders, [[Mezzo Morto Hüseyin Pasha]], then seized command and denounced the cowardice of the Dey, who had agreed to treat with the French. He had him put to death and was acclaimed as his successor by the [[janissaries]]. Before long a red flag, raised from the heights of the [[Casbah]], announced to Duquesne that combat was resumed.{{cite web |url=http://www.vallee-du-ciron.com/Documents/Ouvrages/Michelant/1683.Alger.htm|title=Bombardement d'Alger par Duquesne|last=Michelant |first=L. |date= |website=Faits mémorables de l'histoire de France |publisher= |access-date=21 April 2018 |quote=}} The Algerians replied to the bombs hurled at their city by tying the French consul, [[Jean Le Vacher]] to the mouth of a cannon.{{cite book|author=Daniel Panzac|title=The Barbary Corsairs: The End of a Legend, 1800-1820|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_dyeFP5Hyc4C&pg=PA33|year=2005|publisher=BRILL|isbn=90-04-12594-9|pages=33}} On 28 July pieces of his shattered limbs fell on the decks of the French vessels, along with those of other French prisoners blown to pieces.{{cite book|author=Clement Melchior Justin Maxime Fourcheux de Montrond|title=Les marins les plus celebres. Par ---. 5. ed|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bSxniTA01v0C&pg=PA55|year=1860|publisher=Lefort|pages=55}} Despite the fierce resistance of the Algerians, the city was engulfed by an enormous fire which consumed palaces, mosques, and many other buildings across the city; the wounded could not find any refuge; and ammunition ran low. Algiers would have been reduced to ruins had not Duquesne himself run out of missiles. The bombardment ended on 29 July. The pride of the Algerian pirates was crushed, and as the French fleet returned to France, Algiers sent an embassy under Djiafar-Aga-Effendi to ask forgiveness of Louis XIV, for the injuries and cruelty that the corsairs had inflicted on France.{{cite book|author=Alan G. Jamieson|title=Lords of the Sea: A History of the Barbary Corsairs|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7DlMqY9OQXAC&pg=PA134|date=15 February 2013|publisher=Reaktion Books|isbn=978-1-86189-946-0|pages=134}}{{cite web |url=http://www.vallee-du-ciron.com/Documents/Ouvrages/Michelant/1683.Alger.htm|title=Bombardement d'Alger par Duquesne|last=Michelant |first=L. |date= |website=Faits mémorables de l'histoire de France |publisher= |access-date=21 April 2018 |quote=}} == Aftermath == The new Dey Mezzo Morto Hüseyin Pasha agreed to free another 546 captives,{{cite book|author=Paul Eudel|title=L'orf?vrerie alg?rienne et tunisienne|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iQILAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA35|year=1902|publisher=Рипол Классик|isbn=978-5-87318-342-5|pages=35–}}{{cite book|author=Daniel Panzac|title=The Barbary Corsairs: The End of a Legend, 1800-1820|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_dyeFP5Hyc4C&pg=PA33|year=2005|publisher=BRILL|isbn=90-04-12594-9|pages=33}} but refused to sign a peace agreement with Duquesne, who was then 79 years of age, so Louis XIV sent another envoy, [[Anne Hilarion de Tourville|Tourville]], to treat with him. A hundred year peace was agreed, including a provision to leave the coasts of France unmolested. Five years later, after Algiers violated the treaty, the French again bombarded the city. [[Jean II d'Estrées|Admiral d'Estrées]] obliged the Dey to seek a new peace agreement, signed on 27 September 1688, which the Algerians respected. Thereafter the corsair captains, though they avoided the coasts of France, continued their raids elsewhere, causing considerable damage to the coastal regions of Spain.France. Ministère de la marine et des colonies, ''Revue maritime et coloniale / Ministère de la marine et des colonies'', Librairie de L. Hachette (Paris), 1861-1896, page 663 ==See also== *[[Bombardment of Algiers (1682)]] *[[Bombardment of Algiers (1688)]] == References == {{reflist}} == Bibliography== * {{cite book|language=fr|first1=Michel|last1=Vergé-Franceschi|title=Dictionnaire d'Histoire maritime|sous-titre=|lien titre=|edition=|publisher=éditions Robert Laffont|editorlink=éditions Robert Laffont|location=Paris|year=2002|volume=|tome=|work=Bouquins||page=|isbn=2-221-08751-8|url=|accessdate=|plume=}} * {{cite book|language=fr|first1=Jean|last1=Meyer|first2=Martine|last2=Acerra|title=Histoire de la marine française|sous-titre=|edition=|publisher=éditions Ouest-France|lien éditeur=|location=Rennes|date= 1994|volume=|tome=|page=|isbn=2-7373-1129-2|url=|accessdate=|plume=}} * {{cite book|language=fr|last1=Monaque|first1=Rémi|title=Une histoire de la marine de guerre française|location=Paris|publisher=éditions Perrin|year=2016|isbn=978-2-262-03715-4}} * {{cite book|language=fr|first1=Étienne|last1=Taillemite|title=Dictionnaire des marins français|location=Paris|publisher=éditions Tallandier|year=2002|isbn=2-84734-008-4|plume=}} * {{cite book|language=fr|first1=Lucien|last1=Bély|title=Dictionnaire Louis XIV|publisher=[[éditions Robert Laffont]]|year=2015|work=Bouquins|isbn=978-2-221-12482-6}} * {{cite book|last1=Le Moing|first1=Guy|title=Les 600 plus grandes batailles navales de l'Histoire|publisher=Marines Éditions|year=2011|accessdate=|isbn=978-2-35743-077-8|plume=}} * {{cite book|language=fr|first1=Roland|last1=Courtinat|title=La piraterie barbaresque en Méditerranée: XVIe – XIXe siècle|publisher=Serre Éditeur|year=2003|page=61|url={{google books|plainurl=y|xcLOZOCHf4YC}}}} * {{cite book|language=fr|first1=Jean|last1=Peter|title=Les barbaresques sous Louis XIV: le duel entre Alger et la Marine du Roi (1681-1698)|publisher=Institut de stratégie comparée|year=1997}} * {{cite book|author1=John A. [[File:LittlestownBoroughOfficesSign.jpg|Municipal offices sign for [[Littlestown, Pennsylvania|Littlestown]], a borough of Pennsylvania|thumb|alt=Littlestown borough offices sign.]]
In the [[Commonwealth (U.S. state)|U.S. commonwealth]] of [[Pennsylvania]], a '''borough''' (sometimes spelled '''boro''') is a self-governing [[municipal]] entity, best thought of as a [[town]],<ref name=BB6-61/> usually smaller than a [[city]], but with a similar population density in its residential areas.
==Description== Boroughs also tend to have more developed business districts and concentrations of public and commercial office buildings, including court houses. Both are larger, less spacious, more developed than the relatively rural townships, which often have the greater territory and even surround boroughs of a related or even the same name. There are 958 boroughs and 56 cities in Pennsylvania, but only one town,<ref name="manual 6-3">''The Pennsylvania Manual'', pp. 6–3.</ref> the town of [[Bloomsburg, Pennsylvania|Bloomsburg]].
All municipalities in Pennsylvania are classified as either [[Local government in Pennsylvania#City|cities]], boroughs, or [[township (Pennsylvania)|townships]].<ref name="manual 6-3"/> The only exception is the town of Bloomsburg, which is recognized by state government as the only incorporated town in Pennsylvania<ref name=BB6-61>''The Pennsylvania Manual'', pp. 6–61.</ref> and uses the distinction in its promotion. Many [[Home Rule Municipality (Pennsylvania)|home rule municipalities]] remain classified as boroughs or townships for certain purposes even if the state's Borough and Township Codes no longer apply to them.
==See also== * [[Borough (United States)]] * [[List of towns and boroughs in Pennsylvania]] * [[:Category:Self-governance]]

{{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox organization | name = Campaign for Socialism | logo = Campaign for Socialism.jpg | abbreviation = CfS | formation = 1994 | headquarters = Glasgow | leader_title = Chair | leader_name = Martyn Cook<ref name="left">{{cite|url=http://www.campaignforsocialism.org.uk/contact/]]}}</ref> | leader_title2 = Secretary | leader_name2 = Seán Duffy | leader_title3 = Vice-Chair | leader_name3 = Cara Hilton | website = {{Official website|http://www.campaignforsocialism.org.uk/}} }} '''Campaign for Socialism''' (CfS) is an autonomous [[pressure group]] of [[Scottish Labour Party]] members and supporters who campaign for left-wing policies and candidates within the party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://l-r-c.org.uk/press/news-from-the-scottish-labour-campaign-for-socialism-cfs/|title=News from the Scottish Labour Campaign for Socialism (CfS)|date=7 February 2014|accessdate=6 March 2017}}</ref> In 2016, CfS agreed to a joint membership scheme with [[Momentum (organisation)|Momentum]], a UK-wide [[grassroots movement]] supportive of [[Jeremy Corbyn]] and his leadership of the Labour Party.<ref name=smith2015>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-34609114|title=What is Momentum, and why is it worrying Labour MPs?|publisher=BBC News|date=24 October 2015|author=Norman Smith}}</ref><ref name="JonStone 8Oct Indy">{{cite news|last1=Stone|first1=Jon|title=Jeremy Corbyn's leadership campaign sets up new local activist network called 'Momentum'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jeremy-corbyns-leadership-campaign-sets-up-new-local-activist-network-called-momentum-a6686191.html|accessdate=23 November 2015|work=The Independent|date=8 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151011181318/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jeremy-corbyns-leadership-campaign-sets-up-new-local-activist-network-called-momentum-a6686191.html|archivedate=11 October 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref>
== History == CfS was originally formed in 1994 to campaign against the removal of [[Clause IV]] from the Labour Party's constitution.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://reidfoundation.org/2013/07/scottish-labour-left-attacks-london-interference-in-falkirk-selection-process/|title=Scottish Labour Left attacks London interference in Falkirk Selection Process|date=4 July 2013|accessdate=6 March 2017}}</ref> By 2012, it was one of the only remaining ideological-based groupings in the party {{mdash}} but [[Gerry Hassan]] and Eric Shaw, writing that year, claimed that CfS "has few members, little organisational presence and has had a negligible influence on the direction of the party".<ref>{{cite book|title=The Strange Death of Labour Scotland|page=259|last1=Hassan|first1=Gerry|last2=Shaw|first2=Eric|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|year=2012|isbn=9780748655571}}</ref>
CfS played a key role in organising [[Neil Findlay]] and [[Katy Clark]]'s leadership bid in the [[Scottish Labour Party leadership election, 2014]]. Though unsuccessful, CfS claims the campaign "built the foundations for Jeremy [Corbyn]'s campaign just a few months later" by "giving many new, young volunteers experience and a network of contacts across the country that would help quickly mobilise an effective campaign".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scottishleftreview.org/article/how-the-contest-was-won/|title=How the contest was won|date=November 2015|accessdate=6 March 2017|publisher=[[Scottish Left Review]]}}</ref>
In 2016, Scottish Labour Young Socialists {{mdash}} founded in 2015<ref>{{cite web|url=https://youngsocialists.wordpress.com/2015/08/13/something-different-something-subversive/|title="Something Different, Something Subversive".|date=13 August 2015|accessdate=6 March 2017}}</ref> {{mdash}} became CfS's official youth wing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.workersliberty.org/node/26297|title=Campaign for Socialism AGM discusses way forward|date=18 February 2016|accessdate=6 March 2017|publisher=[[Workers' Liberty]]}}</ref>
In 2017, five CfS members won seats on the Scottish Labour Party's national executive.<ref name="left" /> They called for the then Scottish Labour leader, [[Kezia Dugdale]], to pursue a socialist agenda and work more closely with Jeremy Corbyn's team.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/15134386.Dugdale_loyalists_lost_out_in_Labour_internal_elections_over_bungled_campaign_approach/|title=Dugdale loyalists lost out in Labour internal elections over bungled campaign approach|last=Hutcheon|first=Paul|date=5 March 2017|accessdate=6 March 2017|work=[[Sunday Herald]]}}</ref>
CfS endorsed<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.campaignforsocialism.org.uk/press-releases/2017/9/13/cfs-supports-richard-leonard-for-scottish-labour-leader|title=CfS Supports Richard Leonard for Scottish Labour Leader|work=Campaign for Socialism|access-date=2018-11-26|language=en-US}}</ref> [[Richard Leonard (Scottish politician)|Richard Leonard]] to be the next leader of Scottish Labour following the resignation of Kezia Dugdale in August, 2017. Leonard went on to win the leadership with 56.7% of the vote.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/nov/18/richard-leonard-voted-scottish-labour-leader|title=Richard Leonard wins Scottish Labour leadership in decisive victory|last=Carrell|first=Severin|date=2017-11-18|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref>
Notable members of CfS include former Convenor [[Elaine Smith (Scottish politician)|Elaine Smith MSP]], current Convenor [[Neil Findlay|Neil Findlay MSP]], [[Hugh Gaffney|Hugh Gaffney MP]], and [[Pauline Bryan, Baroness Bryan of Partick|Pauline Bryan]].

The '''chief privacy officer''' (CPO) is a senior level executive within a United States-based business or organization. "Consumer concerns over the use of personal information, including medical data and financial information along with laws and regulations",<ref>{{Cite web|title = Chief Privacy Officer {{!}} DefineFinance|url = http://www.definefinance.com/chief-privacy-officer|website = www.definefinance.com|accessdate = 2015-10-31}}</ref> is one of the key reasons that the CPO role exists, as this was introduced to help keep personal information safe.
There is legislation in different sectors concerning the use of personal information. For example, in medical industry, the protection of patient medical records (e.g. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, or [[HIPAA]]). Another example is in the finance sector with the safeguarding of consumer financial and banking transactions (e.g. The [[Fair Credit Reporting Act]] and its Disposal Rule, and the [[Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act]] and its Safeguards Rule and Financial Privacy Rule).
== History == In the United States, the position of chief information officer was first established at Acxiom Corporation in 1991 with the appointment of Jennifer Barrett as CPO,<ref>https://iapp.org/about/person/0011a00000DlPjEAAV/</ref> with the second appointment of CPO at the Internet advertising firm [[AllAdvantage]] in August 1999, when it appointed privacy lawyer [[Ray Everett-Church]] to the newly created position, starting a trend that quickly spread among major corporations, both offline and online. The role of the Chief Privacy Officer was solidified within the U.S. corporate world in November 2000 with the naming of Harriet Pearson as Chief Privacy Officer for [[IBM|IBM Corporation]]. That event prompted one influential analyst to declare, "the chief privacy officer is a trend whose time has come." <ref>[http://news.cnet.com/IBM+appoints+chief+privacy+officer/2100-1001_3-249135.html news.com IBM appoints chief privacy officer]</ref>
By 2001, the non-profit research organization Privacy and American Business reported that a significant number of [[Fortune 500]] firms had appointed senior executives with the title or role of Chief Privacy Officer. The growth of the Chief Privacy Officer trend was further fueled by the European Union's passage in the late 1990s of [[information privacy|data privacy]] laws and regulations that included a requirement for all corporations to have an individual designated to be accountable for privacy compliance.
By 2002, the position of Chief Privacy Officer and similar privacy-related management positions were sufficiently widespread to support the creation of professional societies and trade associations to promote training and certification programs. In 2002 the largest of these organizations, the Privacy Officers Association and the Association of Corporate Privacy Officers, merged to form the International Association of Privacy Officers, which was later renamed the [[International Association of Privacy Professionals]] (IAPP). The IAPP holds several conferences and training seminars each year around the world, hosting association members from major global corporations and government agencies, with executives seeking certification programs in privacy management practices.
== Responsibilities & Duties ==
Some of the key responsibilities that a CPO has to have are: being able to use business strategies and procedures and apply it to the business, being able to organize plans and lastly looking at privacy program reviews by checking and analyzing the information to ensure it is correct. They are also responsible for making sure data is secure from unauthorized users and making. They would also have to help to improve systems for auditing and monitoring, to therefore resolve any privacy issues.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Current Openings|url = http://www.merkleinc.com/careers/current-openings?gnk=job&gni=8a7880ec5088917c015090c5ff850d3a&gns=Indeed&source=indeed.com#.Vjj9xWvS7Tg|website = Merkle|accessdate = 2015-11-03}}</ref>
As a CPO is responsible for all the privacy of the data in an organization, one major part of their job is to avoid [[Data breach|data breaches]], especially if the organization is a large corporation. However some major companies have been hacked and have data breaches.
These include: *[[eBay]] - up to 145 million customers affected <ref name="infoisbeautiful">{{Cite web|title = World’s Biggest Data Breaches & Hacks {{!}} Information is Beautiful|url = http://www.informationisbeautiful.net/visualizations/worlds-biggest-data-breaches-hacks/|website = www.informationisbeautiful.net|accessdate = 2016-02-13}}</ref> *[[Target Corporation|Target]] - up to 70 million customers affected <ref name="infoisbeautiful" /> *[[Home Depot]] - up to 56 million customers affected <ref name="infoisbeautiful" /> *[[Anthem (company)|Anthem]] - up to 80 million customers affected <ref name="infoisbeautiful" /> *[[JPMorgan Chase|JP Morgan Chase]] - up to 76 million customers affected <ref name="infoisbeautiful" />
Data breaches are commonly high-profile events and not only the reputation of the CPO will be affected but also the company's reputation, impacting consumer confidence.
== Qualities == One key quality a CPO will need to have is being good at communicating,<ref>{{Cite web|title = The 7 habits of highly effective CPOs - Supply Business|url = http://www.supplybusiness.com/previous-articles/winter-2009-2010/features/the-7-habits-of-highly-effective-cpos/|website = www.supplybusiness.com|accessdate = 2015-10-25}}</ref> because poor communication could lead to a leakage of data which the CPO would be accountable for.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Government Chief Privacy Officer {{!}} ICT.govt.nz|url = https://www.ict.govt.nz/governance-and-leadership/the-gcio-team/government-chief-privacy-officer/|website = www.ict.govt.nz|accessdate = 2015-10-31}}</ref> Another quality a CPO should have is staying aware of any new developments and risks in the field.
== Benefits and drawbacks == There are some major benefits to having a CPO in your organization. The first would be that they help to keep data secure, so this ensures that security of data is not compromised. Another benefit is that they help develop policies which is why "''30% of CPOs are attorneys''" and "''15% are in the information security department''".<ref>{{Cite web|title = Why your company needs a chief privacy officer|url = http://www.networkworld.com/article/2290212/lan-wan/why-your-company-needs-a-chief-privacy-officer.html|website = Network World|accessdate = 2015-10-25}}</ref> Therefore, this means that CPO can legally help to ensure that the data stays secure.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Chief Privacy Officer|url = https://hbr.org/2000/11/chief-privacy-officer|website = Harvard Business Review|accessdate = 2015-10-25}}</ref> In terms of what industries a CPO can be beneficial, a CPO would be favorable in almost every sector. For example, the finance sector is perhaps one of the main areas where you are dealing with consumer information. It's not just the finance sector, basically anywhere you have and store customers information, a CPO would be a good idea as they will help to ensure that customers data is safe.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Does Your Company Need A Chief Privacy Officer?|url = http://www.informationintersection.com/2012/10/does-your-company-need-a-chief-privacy-officer/|website = Information Intersection|accessdate = 2015-10-25}}</ref>
There are also some drawbacks to having a CPO in your organization, the first being cost. According to [[payscale.com]] the average salary for a CPO in the United States is over 6 figures, roughly about $107,000 per year.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Chief Privacy & Security Officer Salary|url = http://www.payscale.com/research/US/Job=Chief_Privacy_%2526_Security_Officer/Salary|website = www.payscale.com|accessdate = 2015-10-29}}</ref> Another drawback to having a CPO in your business would be that some may argue that it's just too much power for one person to have, especially if they are dealing with personal information{{who|date=November 2015}}.
==See also== *[[Privacy Office of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security]] *[[Chief Privacy Officer, Department of Homeland Security]]

'''Christianity and colonialism''' are often closely associated because [[Catholicism]] and [[Protestantism]] were the [[religions]] of the [[European colonial powers]]{{cite book |title=Colonialism: an international, social, cultural, and political encyclopedia, Volume 1 |page=496 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |year=2003 |quote=Of all religions, Christianity has been most associated with colonialism because several of its forms (Catholicism and Protestantism) were the religions of the European powers engaged in colonial enterprise on a global scale. |author=Melvin E. Page, Penny M. Sonnenburg}} and acted in many ways as the "[[religious arm]]" of those powers.{{cite web |first=Steven |last=Bevans |title=Christian Complicity in Colonialism/ Globalism |url=http://www.secondenlightenment.org/Christian%20Complicity.pdf |accessdate=2010-11-17 |quote=The modern missionary era was in many ways the ‘religious arm’ of colonialism, whether Portuguese and Spanish colonialism in the sixteenth Century, or British, French, German, Belgian or American colonialism in the nineteenth. This was not all bad — oftentimes missionaries were heroic defenders of the rights of indigenous peoples}} According to Edward Andrews, Christian missionaries were initially portrayed as "visible [[saints]], exemplars of ideal piety in a sea of persistent savagery". However, by the time the colonial era drew to a close in the last half of the twentieth century, missionaries became viewed as "ideological [[shock troops]] for colonial invasion whose [[zealotry]] blinded them",{{cite journal |first=Edward |last=Andrews |journal=Journal of Church & State |title=Christian Missions and Colonial Empires Reconsidered: A Black Evangelist in West Africa, 1766–1816 |year=2010 |doi=10.1093/jcs/csp090 |url=http://jcs.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2010/03/04/jcs.csp090|volume=51 |issue=4 |pages=663–691}} colonialism's "agent, scribe and moral alibi."{{cite book | last1 = Comaroff | first1 = Jean | last2 = Comaroff | first2 = John | year = 2010 | origyear = 1997 | chapter = Africa Observed: Discourses of the Imperial Imagination | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=myLOFYZ4dQ0C&pg=PA31 | editor1-last = Grinker | editor1-first = Roy R. | editor2-last = Lubkemann | editor2-first = Stephen C. | editor3-last = Steiner | editor3-first = Christopher B. | title = Perspectives on Africa: A Reader in Culture, History and Representation | edition = 2nd | location = Oxford | publisher = Blackwell Publishing | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=myLOFYZ4dQ0C&pg=PA32 32]}} [[Christianity]] is targeted by critics of colonialism because the tenets of the religion were used to justify the actions of the [[colonists]].{{cite web |first=Jake |last=Meador |title=Cosmetic Christianity and the Problem of Colonialism – Responding to Brian McLaren |url=http://notesfromasmallplace.wordpress.com/2010/09/17/cosmetic-christianity-and-the-problem-of-colonialism-responding-to-brian-mclaren/|accessdate=2010-11-17 |quote=According to Jake Meador, "some Christians have tried to make sense of post-colonial Christianity by renouncing practically everything about the Christianity of the colonizers. They reason that if the colonialists’ understanding of Christianity could be used to justify rape, murder, theft, and empire then their understanding of Christianity is completely wrong.}} For example, Toyin Falola asserts that there were some missionaries who believed that "the agenda of colonialism in Africa was similar to that of Christianity".{{cite book |title=Violence in Nigeria: The Crisis of Religious Politics and Secular Ideologies |first=Toyin |last=Falola |publisher=University Rochester Press |year=2001 |page=33}} Falola cites Jan H. Boer of the Sudan United Mission as saying, "Colonialism is a form of imperialism based on a divine mandate and designed to bring liberation - spiritual, cultural, economic and political - by sharing the blessings of the Christ-inspired civilization of the West with a people suffering under satanic oppression, ignorance and disease, effected by a combination of political, economic and religious forces that cooperate under a regime seeking the benefit of both ruler and ruled." Edward Andrews writes:
Historians have traditionally looked at Christian missionaries in one of two ways. The first church historians to catalogue missionary history provided hagiographic descriptions of their trials, successes, and sometimes even martyrdom. Missionaries were thus visible saints, exemplars of ideal piety in a sea of persistent savagery. However, by the middle of the twentieth century, an era marked by civil rights movements, anti-colonialism, and growing secularization, missionaries were viewed quite differently. Instead of godly martyrs, historians now described missionaries as arrogant and rapacious imperialists. Christianity became not a saving grace but a monolithic and aggressive force that missionaries imposed upon defiant natives. Indeed, missionaries were now understood as important agents in the ever-expanding nation-state, or "ideological shock troops for colonial invasion whose zealotry blinded them."
According to Jake Meador, "some Christians have tried to make sense of post-colonial Christianity by renouncing practically everything about the Christianity of the colonizers. They reason that if the colonialists’ understanding of Christianity could be used to justify rape, murder, theft, and empire then their understanding of Christianity is completely wrong. "{{cite web|first=Jake |last=Meador |title=Cosmetic Christianity and the Problem of Colonialism – Responding to Brian McLaren|url=http://notesfromasmallplace.wordpress.com/2010/09/17/cosmetic-christianity-and-the-problem-of-colonialism-responding-to-brian-mclaren/|accessdate=2010-11-17}} According to Lamin Sanneh, "(m)uch of the standard Western scholarship on Christian missions proceeds by looking at the motives of individual missionaries and concludes by faulting the entire missionary enterprise as being part of the machinery of Western cultural imperialism." As an alternative to this view, Sanneh presents a different perspective arguing that "missions in the modern era have been far more, and far less, than the argument about motives customarily portrayed."{{cite journal |journal=The Christian Century |date=April 8, 1987 |pages=331–334 |publisher=The Christian Century Foundation |title=Christian Missions and the Western Guilt Complex |first=Lamin |last=Sanneth |url=http://www.religion-online.org/showarticle.asp?title=143 |accessdate=2010-12-02}} Michael Wood asserts that the [[indigenous peoples]] were not considered to be human beings and that the colonisers was shaped by "centuries of [[Ethnocentrism]], and [[Christian monotheism]], which espoused one truth, one time and version of reality."Conquistadors, Michael Wood, p. 20, BBC Publications, 2000 ==Age of Discovery== {{Further|Colonialism|Age of Discovery|Catholic Church and the Age of Discovery}} [[Image:Convento san agustin 2.jpg|thumb|200px| The convent of San Augustin. A mission centre established at Yuriria, Mexico in 1550]] During the [[Age of Discovery]], the [[Catholic Church]] inaugurated a major effort to spread Christianity in the New World and to convert the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]] and other indigenous people. The missionary effort was a major part of, and a partial justification for the colonial efforts of European powers such as [[Spain]], [[France]] and [[Portugal]]. Christian [[Mission (Christian)|Missions]] to the indigenous peoples ran hand-in-hand with the colonial efforts of Catholic nations. In the Americas and other colonies in Asia and Africa, most missions were run by religious orders such as the [[Augustinians]], [[Franciscans]], [[Jesuits]] and [[Dominican Order|Dominicans]]. In both [[Portugal]] and [[Spain]], religion was an integral part of the state and evangelization was seen as having both secular and spiritual benefits. Wherever these powers attempted to expand their territories or influence, missionaries would soon follow. By the [[Treaty of Tordesillas]], the two powers divided the world between them into exclusive spheres of influence, trade and colonization. The Roman Catholic world order was challenged by the [[Netherlands]] and [[England]]. Theoretically, it was repudiated by [[Grotius]]'s ''Mare Liberum''. Portugal's and Spain's colonial policies were also challenged by the Roman Catholic Church itself. The [[Holy See|Vatican]] founded the [[Congregatio de Propaganda Fide]] in 1622 and attempted to separate the churches from the influence of the [[Iberian Peninsula|Iberian]] kingdoms. ==Americas== Jan van Butselaar writes that "for [[Prince Henry the Navigator]] and his contemporaries, the colonial enterprise was based on the necessity to develop European commerce and the obligation to propagate the Christian faith."{{cite book |title=Bridge or barrier: religion, violence, and visions for peace, Volume 2001 |editors=Gerrie ter Haar, James J. Busuttil |publisher=BRILL |year=2005 |page=125}} Christian leaders and Christian doctrines have been accused of justifying and perpetrating violence against Native Americans found in the New World.Carroll, Vincent, ''Christianity on trial: arguments against anti-religious bigotry'', p 87. ===Spanish missionaries=== {{main|Spanish missions in the Americas}} Adriaan van Oss wrote:
If we had to choose a single, irreducible idea underlying Spanish colonialism in the New World, it would undoubtedly be the propagation of the Catholic faith. Unlike such other European as England or the Netherlands, Spain insisted on converting the natives of the lands it conquered to its state religion. Miraculously, it succeeded. Introduced in the context of Iberian expansionism, Catholicism outlived the empire itself and continues to thrive, not as an anachronistic vestige among the elite, but as a vital current even in remote mountain villages. Catholicism remains the principal colonial heritage of Spain in America. More than any set of economic relationships with the outside world, more even than the language first brought to America's shores in 1492, the Catholic religion continues to permeate Spanish-American culture today, creating an overriding cultural unity which transcends the political and national boundaries dividing the continent.{{cite book |title=Catholic Colonialism: A Parish History of Guatemala, 1524-1821 |first=Adriaan C. |last=van Oss }}
The Spaniards were committed, by Vatican decree, to convert their [[New World]] indigenous subjects to Catholicism. However, often initial efforts were questionably successful, as the indigenous people added [[Catholicism]] into their longstanding traditional ceremonies and beliefs. The many native expressions, forms, practices, and items of art could be considered idolatry and prohibited or destroyed by Spanish missionaries, military, and civilians. This included religious items, sculptures, and jewelry made of gold or silver, which were melted down before shipment to Spain.{{cite news |first=Brenda |last=Golden |title=A Native Take on Terrorism, the Towers and Tolerance |date=2010-08-24 }} Though the Spanish did not impose their language to the extent they did their religion, some [[indigenous languages of the Americas]] evolved into replacement with Spanish, and lost to present day tribal members. When more efficient they did evangelize in native languages. Introduced writing systems to the Quechua, Nahuatl and Guarani peoples may have contributed to their expansion.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} In the early years most mission work was undertaken by the religious orders. Over time it was intended that a normal church structure would be established in the mission areas. The process began with the formation of special jurisdictions, known as apostolic prefectures and apostolic vicariates. These developing churches eventually graduated to regular diocesan status with the appointment of a local bishop. After [[decolonization]], this process increased in pace as church structures altered to reflect new political-administrative realities. Hastings, Adrian, ''A World History of Christianity'', Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing, 2000, pp 330-349 Ralph Bauer describes the Franciscan missionaries as having been "unequivocally committed to Spanish imperialism, condoning the violence and coercion of the Conquest as the only viable method of bringing American natives under the saving rule of Christianity."{{cite book |title=Finding colonial Americas: essays honoring J.A. Leo Lemay |first=Ralph |last=Bauer |publisher=University of Delaware Press |year=2001 |page=35 }} Jordan writes "The catastrophe of Spanish America's rape at the hands of the Conquistadors remains one of the most potent and pungent examples in the entire history of human conquest of the wanton destruction of one culture by another in the name of religion""In the Name of God : Violence and Destruction in the World's Religions", M. Jordan, 2006, p. 230 [[Antonio de Montesinos (Dominican friar)|Antonio de Montesinos]], a Dominican [[friar]] on the island of [[Hispaniola]], was the first member of the clergy to publicly denounce all forms of enslavement and oppression of the [[indigenous peoples of the Americas]].Hanke, Lewis. (1946) Free Speech in Sixteenth-Century Spanish America. ''The Hispanic American Historical Review'', 26,2:135-149. Page 142. Theologians such as [[Francisco de Vitoria]] and [[Bartolomé de las Casas]] drew up theological and philosophical bases for the defense of the [[human rights]] of the colonized native populations, thus creating the basis of [[international law]], regulating the relationships between nations. ===French missions=== {{main|French colonization of the Americas|France Équinoxiale|Protectorate of missions}} The French colonial effort began later than that of the Spanish or Portuguese. ::Hawaii - The French Incident (1839) Under the rule of Ka{{okina}}ahumanu the newly converted Protestant widow of Kamehameha the Great, Catholicism was illegal in Hawaii and chiefs loyal to her forcibly deported French priests onto the ''Artemise''. [[Native Hawaiian]] Catholic converts were imprisoned and [[American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions#Early missions|Protestant ministers]] ordered them to be tortured. The prejudice against the French Catholics missionaries remained the same under the reign of her successor, the [[Kuhina Nui]] [[Ka'ahumanu II]]. In 1839 [[Cyrille Pierre Théodore Laplace|Captain Laplace]] of the French frigate ''Artémise'' sailed to Hawaii under orders to:
Destroy the malevolent impression which you find established to the detriment of the French name; to rectify the erroneous opinion which has been created as to the power of France; and to make it well understood that it would be to the advantage of the chiefs of those islands of the Ocean to conduct themselves in such a manner as not to incur the wrath of France. You will exact, if necessary with all the force that is yours to use, complete reparation for the wrongs which have been committed, and you will not quit those places until you have left in all minds a solid and lasting impression.{{Cite quote|date=October 2009}}
==Asia and the Far East== Christian missionaries had mixed success in the Far East. After initial success in Japan, the government crackdown and destroy the Christian missions; they never recovered. In China there was limited success in some places. In India, the British missionaries were often in conflict with British administrators and businessmen. Missionaries had moderate success among the scheduled classes. In French-controlled Vietnam, and a Japanese-controlled Korea, the Christian missionaries had significant success in terms of membership.Samuel Hugh Moffett, ''A History of Christianity in Asia, Vol. II: 1500-1900'' (2003) [https://www.amazon.com/History-Christianity-Asia-Vol-1500-1900/dp/1570757011/ online]. Christianity had a more subtle effect, reaching far beyond the converted population to potential modernizers. The introduction of European medicine was especially important, as well as the introduction of European political practices and ideals ideals such as religious liberty, mass education, mass printing, newspapers, voluntary organizations, colonial reforms, and especially liberal democracy. Robert D. Woodberry, "The missionary roots of liberal democracy." ''American Political Science Review'' 106#2 (2012): 244-274. [http://www.hillcountryinstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/missionaryrootsofliberaldemocracy.pdf online] ==Africa== Christian evangelists were intimately involved in the colonial process in southern Africa.{{cite journal |title=Christianity and Colonialism in South Africa b|first1=Jean |last1=Comaroff |first2=John |last2=Comaroff |journal=American Ethnologist |volume=13 |year=1986 |pages=1–22 |issue=1 |doi=10.1525/ae.1986.13.1.02a00010}} The Portuguese sent missions into Africa. In the mid-19th century, [[Protestantism|Protestant]] missions were engaged in active missionary work on the Guinea coast, in South Africa and in the Zanzibar dominions. Missionaries visited little-known regions and peoples, and in many instances became explorers and pioneers of trade and empire. [[David Livingstone]], a Scottish missionary, had been engaged since 1840 in work north of the [[Orange River]]. According to Heather Sharkey, the real impact of the activities of the missionaries is still a topic open to debate in academia today. Sharkey asserted that "the missionaries played manifold roles in colonial Africa and stimulated forms of cultural, political and religious change." "Historians still debate the nature of their impact and question their relation to the system of European colonialism in the continent."{{cite web |title=Religion in colonial Africa |first=Taimur |last=Khan |date=2002-10-29 |accessdate=2010-11-17 |url=http://www.thedp.com/article/2002/10/religion_in_colonial_africa}} According to Sharkey, some observers believe that the missionaries did great good in Africa, providing crucial social services such as education and health care that would have otherwise not been available to the Africans. Sharkey said that, in societies that were traditionally male-dominated, female missionaries provided women in Africa with health care knowledge and basic education. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * Cleall, Esme. ''Missionary discourses of difference: Negotiating otherness in the British Empire, 1840-1900'' (2012). * Moffett, Samuel Hugh. ''A History of Christianity in Asia, Vol. II: 1500-1900'' (2003) [https://www.amazon.com/History-Christianity-Asia-Vol-1500-1900/dp/1570757011/ref=tmm_pap_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&qid=1519541778&sr=1-1 excerpt] * Mong, Ambrose. ''Guns and Gospels: Imperialism and Evangelism in China'' (James Clarke Company, 2016). *[[K. M. Panikkar|Panikkar, K. M.]]. ''Asia and Western dominance, 1498-1945'' (Allen and Unwin, 1953) * Porter, Andrew. ''Religion Versus Empire?: British Protestant missionaries and overseas expansion, 1700-1914'' (2004) * Porter, Andrew. ''The Imperial Horizons of British Protestant Missions, 1880-1914'' (2003) * Prevost, Elizabeth. "Assessing Women, Gender, and Empire in Britain's Nineteenth‐Century Protestant Missionary Movement." ''History Compass'' 7#3 (2009): 765-799. * Stanley, Brian. ''The Bible and the Flag: Protestant Mission and British Imperialism in the 19th and 20th Centuries'' (1990) * Stuart, John. "Beyond sovereignty?: Protestant missions, empire and transnationalism, 1890–1950." in y Maryann Cusimano Love ed., ''Beyond sovereignty'' (Palgrave Macmillan, London, 2007) pp 103-125. * Ward, Kevin & Brian Stanley, eds. ''Church Mission Society & World Christianity. 1799-1999' (1999) * Wu, Albert. "Ernst Faber and the Consequences of Failure: A study of a nineteenth-century German missionary in China." ''Central European History'' 47.1 (2014): 1-29. {{Colonization}} {{Indigenous rights footer}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Christianity And Colonialism}} [[Category:Colonialism]] [[Category:Early Modern history of Christianity]] [[Category:Christianity and society|Colonialism]]

{{unreferenced|date=December 2013}} The '''Court of Audits''' (in [[Dutch language|Dutch]]: ''Algemene Rekenkamer'') is an independent body that [[audit]]s the spending of the national government on its [[Economic efficiency|efficiency]] and [[legitimacy (political)|legitimacy]]. The Court is appointed by [[cabinet of the Netherlands|cabinet]] on the advice of the [[House of Representatives of the Netherlands|House of Representatives]]. The Court of Audit is a [[High Council of State (Netherlands)|High Council of State]].
==Similar institutions== *[[Audit Scotland]] *[[Auditor General of Canada]] *[[Comptroller and Auditor General]] *[[Cour des Comptes]] (France) *[[Government Accountability Office]] (USA) *[[National Audit Office (United Kingdom)|United Kingdom National Audit Office]] *[[Audit Board of Indonesia|Badan Pemeriksa Keuangan]] (Indonesia)

{{canon law}} '''Derogation''' is the partial suppression of a law,<ref name=DellaRocca>Manual of Canon Law, pg. 69</ref> as opposed to [[Repeal|abrogation]]—total abolition of a law by explicit [[repeal]]—and [[obrogation]]—the partial or total modification or repeal of a law by the imposition of a later and contrary one. The term is used in [[canon law (Catholic Church)|canon law]],<ref name=DellaRocca/> [[Civil law (legal system)|civil law]], and [[common law]]. It is sometimes used, loosely, to mean abrogation, as in the legal maxim: ''Lex posterior derogat priori'', i.e. a subsequent law imparts the abolition of a previous one.
Derogation differs from [[dispensation (canon law)|dispensation]] in that it applies to the law, whereas dispensation applies to specific people affected by the law.
==Canon law== {{main|Canon law (Catholic Church)}} {{see also|Jurisprudence of canon law}} That is to say, in canon law a ''dispensation'' affirms the validity of a law, but asserts that the law will not be held to apply to one or more specific persons, for a specific reason. (For example, while the Catholic Church's canon law does not normally recognise gender transition, an [[intersex]] woman may present appropriate medical documentation to seek, and possibly receive, a dispensation from the Holy See to live and be recognised as a man, or vice versa.) ''Derogation'', on the other hand, affects the ''general'' applicability of a law.
A non-canon-law analogue of dispensation might be the issuing of a [[zoning variance]] to a particular business, while a general rezoning applied to all properties in an area is more analogous to derogation.
==European Union law== {{main|European Union law}} In terms of [[European Union]] legislation, a derogation can also imply that a member state delays the implementation of an element of an EU [[Regulation (European Union)|Regulation]] (etc.) into their legal system over a given timescale,<ref>[http://esharp.eu/jargon/derogation/ Derogation – EU Jargon]</ref> such as five years; or that a member state has opted not to enforce a specific provision in a treaty due to internal circumstances (typically a state of emergency).
==See also == * [[Implied repeal]] * [[Obrogation]] * [[Repeal]] * [[State of emergency]]
==References== {{reflist}} ===Bibliography=== * [[Fernando Della Rocca|Della Rocca, F.]] (1959) (trans. Rev. [[Anselm Thatcher]], [[O.S.B.]]), ''Manual of Canon Law''. Milwaukee: The [[Bruce Publishing Company]].
==External links== * [http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/04739b.htm ''Catholic Encyclopedia'' Derogation]

{{Infobox Governor |name = Diepreye Alamieyeseigha |image = ChiefDiepreyeAlamieyeseigha.jpg |width = 200px |caption = Diepreye Alamieyeseigha (right) with U.S. Ambassador to Nigeria Howard F. Jeter (left), July 6, 2001 |office1 = Governor of Bayelsa State |term_start1 = 29 May 1999 |term_end1 = 9 December 2005 |predecessor1 = [[Paul Obi]] |successor1 = [[Goodluck Jonathan]] |birth_date = 16 November 1952 |birth_place = [[Amassoma]], [[Bayelsa State]], [[Nigeria]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|df=y|2015|10|10|1952|11|16}} |death_place = [[Port Harcourt]], [[Rivers State]], Nigeria |party = }}
'''Diepreye Solomon Peter Alamieyeseigha''' ("DSP") (16 November 1952 – 10 October 2015) was a Nigerian politician who was [[List of Governors of Bayelsa State|Governor]] of [[Bayelsa State]] in [[Nigeria]] from 29 May 1999 to 9 December 2005.
==Background==
Diepreye Alamieyeseigha was born on 16 November 1952 in [[Amassoma]], [[Ogboin North]] [[Local Government Areas of Nigeria|Local Government Area]], [[Bayelsa State]]. He attended the Bishop Dimeari Grammar School, [[Yenagoa]]. He joined the Nigerian Defence Academy as a Cadet Officer in 1974, then joined the Nigerian Air Force, where he served in the department of Logistics and Supply. He held various air force positions in [[Enugu]], [[Makurdi]], [[Kaduna]] and [[Ikeja]]. Alamieyeseigha retired from the air force in 1992 as a Squadron Leader.<ref name=newsprof>{{cite web |url=http://ndn.nigeriadailynews.com/templates/?a=20227 |title=Alamieyeseigha, 57 and unrepentant |date=November 16, 2009 |publisher=Nigeria Daily News |accessdate=2009-12-05}}</ref>
After leaving the air force he became the Sole Administrator of Pabod Supplies Port Harcourt. Later he became Head of Budget, Planning, Research and Development of the National Fertiliser Company (NAFCON).<ref name=newsprof/>
==Governor of Bayelsa State==
Diepreye Alamieyeseigha was elected as Governor of Bayelsa State in May 1999 as a member of the ruling [[People's Democratic Party (Nigeria)|People's Democratic Party]] (PDP). He was re-elected in 2003.<ref name=Basel>{{cite web |url=http://www.assetrecovery.org/kc/node/24d05648-b4b0-11dd-a1f9-7986f5e51dc8.0;jsessionid=3A4E96D150E4C139329FB6680BC5162A |title=Diepreye Alamieyeseigha |publisher=Basel Institute on Governance |accessdate=2009-12-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140318120957/http://www.assetrecovery.org/kc/node/24d05648-b4b0-11dd-a1f9-7986f5e51dc8.0 |archivedate=2014-03-18 |df= }}</ref> Vice President [[Atiku Abubakar]] attended the March 2003 event that kicked of his campaign for reelection in 2003.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.thisdayonline.com/political/20030320pol01.html |title = Atiku in Yenagoa, Reconciles Alamieyeseigha, Alaibe |author = Chukwudi Nwabuko |publisher = ThisDay |date = 2003-03-20 |accessdate = 2009-12-05 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091018043530/http://www.thisdayonline.com/political/20030320pol01.html |archivedate = 2009-10-18 |df = }}</ref>
==Corruption charges==
===United Kingdom=== Diepreye Alamieyeseigha was detained in London on charges of money laundering in September 2005. At the time of his arrest, Metropolitan police found about £1m in cash in his London home. Later they found a total of £1.8m ($3.2m) in cash and bank accounts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4462444.stm |title=Nigeria governor to be impeached |date=23 November 2005 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2009-12-05}}</ref> He was found to own four homes in London<ref name =icij /> worth an alleged £10 million.{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} His state's monthly federal allocation for the last six years has been in the order of £32 million.{{Citation needed|date=July 2007}} He jumped bail in December 2005 from the [[United Kingdom]] by allegedly disguising himself as a woman, though Alamieyeseigha denies this claim.<ref name=BBCprof>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4499962.stm |publisher=BBC News |title=Nigeria's runaway governor |date=6 December 2005 |accessdate=2009-12-05}}</ref>
Alamieyeseigha was impeached on allegations of corruption on 9 December 2005.<ref name=Basel/>
===Nigeria===
On July 26, 2007, Alamieyeseigha pleaded guilty before a Nigerian court to six charges and was sentenced to two years in prison on each charge; however, because the sentences were set to run concurrently and the time was counted from the point of his arrest nearly two years before the sentences, his actual sentence was relatively short. Many of his assets were ordered to be forfeited to the Bayelsa state government. According to Alamieyeseigha, he only pleaded guilty due to his age and would have fought the charges had he been younger.<ref>Adesina Aiyekoti, [http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/news/national/2007/july/27/national-27-07-2007-001.htm "Corruption: Alamieyeseigha pleads guilty, bags 12 years jail term"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929083225/http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/news/national/2007/july/27/national-27-07-2007-001.htm |date=2007-09-29 }}, ''Daily Sun'' (Nigeria), July 27, 2007.</ref> On July 27, just hours after being taken to prison, he was released due to time already served.<ref name=IHT>{{cite web |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/07/28/africa/AF-POL-Nigeria-Corruption.php |title=Former Nigerian state governor freed a day after corruption conviction |publisher=Associated Press (International Herald Tribune) |date=July 28, 2007}}</ref>
In April 2009, Alamieyeseigha pledged a donation of 3,000,000 naira to the Akassa Development Foundation.<ref>http://www.pronatura-nigeria.org</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://thenationonlineng.net/the-man-dsp-alamieyeseigha/|title=The man DSP Alamieyeseigha |publisher=The Nation |date=Oct 11, 2015 |accessdate=2016-09-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.takemetonaija.com/2015/10/the-late-diepreye-alamieyeseigha.html|title=T.I.N MAGAZINE: The Late Diepreye Alamieyeseigha: Biography, Life,History, And Death|website=www.takemetonaija.com}}</ref>
In December 2009, the federal government hired a British law firm to help dispose of four expensive properties acquired by Alamieyeseigha in [[London]]. Alamieyeseigha had bought one of these properties for £1,750,000.00 in July 2003, paying in cash. Diepreye Solomon Peter Alamieyeseigha used it as his London residence, and as the registered office of Solomon and Peters Inc.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/News/National/5451341-147/story.csp |title = Alamieyeseigha’s London properties for sale |author = Musikilu Mojeed |date = December 2, 2009 |publisher = 234Next |accessdate = 2009-12-05 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091120153416/http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/News/National/5451341-147/story.csp |archivedate = 2009-11-20 |df = }}</ref>
===United States===
On June 28, 2012, the United States (US) Department of Justice (DoJ) announced that it had executed an asset forfeiture order on $401,931 in a Massachusetts brokerage fund, traceable to Alamieyeseigha. US prosecutors filed court papers in April 2011 targeting the Massachusetts brokerage fund and a $600,000 home in Rockville,<ref name=icij>{{cite news |url = http://www.panamapapers.icij.org/20160725-natural-resource-africa-offshore.html |title = Secret Offshore Deals Deprive Africa of Billions in Natural Resource Dollars |author = Will Fitzgibbon |publisher = International Consortium of Investigative Journalists |date = July 25, 2016 |accessdate = August 28, 2016 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160828223630/https://panamapapers.icij.org/20160725-natural-resource-africa-offshore.html |archive-date = 2016-08-28 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> Maryland, which they alleged were the proceeds of corruption. A motion for default judgement and civil forfeiture was granted by a Massachusetts federal district judge in early June 2012. The forfeiture order was the first to be made under the DoJ’s fledgling [[Kleptocracy Asset Recovery Initiative]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/2012/June/12-crm-827.html|title=Department of Justice Forfeits More Than $400,000 in Corruption Proceeds Linked to Former Nigerian Governor|website=www.justice.gov}}</ref><ref> {{cite news|url=http://blogs.wsj.com/corruption-currents/2012/06/28/doj-executes-forfeiture-on-us-assets-of-former-nigerian-gov/| title=DOJ Executes Forfeiture on US Assets of Former Nigerian Gov.| author=Christopher M. Matthews| publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]| date=28 June 2012}}</ref>
===Pardon===
On 12 March 2013, Alamieyeseigha was [[pardon]]ed by President [[Goodluck Jonathan]], but his pardoning was criticised by many.<ref name=ThePunch>{{cite news|url=http://www.punchng.com/news/outrage-over-presidential-pardon-for-vip-ex-convicts/ |title=Outrage over presidential pardon for VIP ex-convicts |author=Olusola Fabiyi |author2=Olalekan Adetayo |last-author-amp=yes |newspaper=[[The Punch]] |publisher=Ajibola Ogunsola |date=13 March 2013 |accessdate=14 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130314190727/http://www.punchng.com/news/outrage-over-presidential-pardon-for-vip-ex-convicts/ |archivedate=14 March 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name=Vanguard(Nigeria)>{{cite news |url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2013/03/no-apologies-over-pardon-for-alamieyeseigha-others-presidency/ |title=No apologies over pardon for Alamieyeseigha, others – Presidency |author= |newspaper=[[Vanguard (Nigeria)]] |publisher=Vanguard Media |date=14 March 2013 |accessdate=14 March 2013}}</ref>
==Death== Alamieyeseigha was reported to have died of cardiac arrest at the [[University of Port Harcourt Teaching Hospital]] on 10 October 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.channelstv.com/2015/10/10/former-bayelsa-governor-diepreye-alamieyeseigha-is-dead/|publisher=Channels Television|accessdate=October 10, 2015|date=October 10, 2015|title=Former Bayelsa Governor, Diepreye Alamieyeseigha Is Dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.punchng.com/news/alamieyeseigha-dies-of-high-blood-pressure/ |title=Alamieyeseigha dies of high blood pressure |publisher=The Punch |author1=Chukwidi Asakie |author2=Simon Utebor |date=October 11, 2015 |accessdate=October 11, 2015 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> However, in a later interview, Bayelsa State Information Commissioner, Esueme Kikile revealed that the former Governor "died of complications arising from high blood pressure and diabetes which affected his kidney."<ref>{{cite news|title=How Alamieyeseigha died – Bayelsa Government|url=http://www.premiumtimesng.com/regional/south-south-regional/191363-how-alamieyeseigha-died-bayelsa-government.html|accessdate=13 October 2015|work=Premium Times|date=11 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thenews.ng/metro/ten-things-you-should-know-about-late-diepreye-alamieyeseigha/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160815124242/https://www.thenews.ng/metro/ten-things-you-should-know-about-late-diepreye-alamieyeseigha/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=15 August 2016|title=Ten Things You Should Know About Late Diepreye Alamieyeseigha|last=|first=|date=12 October 2015|website=|publisher=thenews.ng|access-date=|work=Opemipo Adeniyi|accessdate=20 October 2015}}</ref>

{{Infobox civil conflict | title = Dongzhou protests | partof = [[Human rights in the People's Republic of China]] | image = | caption = | date = 2005-2006 | place = [[Dongzhou]] (东洲) | coordinates = | causes = Land grabs in China | goals = | methods = | status = | result = | side1 = Local farmers and villagers | side2 = [[People's Armed Police]] | side3 = | leadfigures1 = | leadfigures2 = | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | fatalities = Unknown; three to several dozen | injuries = | arrests = | detentions = Police commander was detained for mishandling the protest and causing deaths and injuries. | charged = 19 villagers have been charged and prosecuted for the unrest, 7 of whom have been given long sentences. | fined = | casualties_label = | notes = }}
The '''Dongzhou protests''' refers to a series of protests that took place for seven months until December 2005 in [[Dongzhou, Guangdong|Dongzhou]] (东洲), a village in [[Shanwei]] [[prefecture-level city|prefecture]], [[Guangdong|Guangdong Province]], [[China]]. The protests were organized in opposition to government plans to partially [[infill]] the bay and build a new power plant. It resulted in the shooting deaths of several villagers in the night of 6 December 2005 by [[People's Armed Police]]. The death toll is unknown, with different sources mentioning anywhere from three to several dozen deaths. The protests resumed in November 2006.
==Incident==
The protests were held because local farmers were dissatisfied with the lack of compensation for land expropriated for the construction of the plant. They are also reportedly concerned with the potential for harmful pollution affecting their crops, while fishermen felt their livelihood would be adversely affected by the modifications to the bay.
According to ''[[Xinhua]]'', the Information Office of the government of Shanwei described the incident as "serious violation of law", in which Huang Xijun, Lin Hanru and Huang Xirang led protesters in attacking police with knives, [[petrol bomb]]s, and other explosive devices. Xinhua reported that the police fired warning shots but, in the confusion after nightfall, people were hit by mistake.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gd.xinhuanet.com/gdnews/2005-12/11/content_5789418.htm |title=新华网广东频道 - 广东省汕尾市红海湾开发区发生严重违法事件 |publisher=Gd.xinhuanet.com |date=2005-12-11 |accessdate=2013-07-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130214105602/http://gd.xinhuanet.com/gdnews/2005-12/11/content_5789418.htm |archivedate=14 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Local villagers denied these accounts, reported that the protesters may have used ordinary [[fireworks]] as part of their protest. Villagers also alleged that the authorities had "enlisted thugs from local organized crime groups to help put down the demonstration" in addition to regular security forces.<ref>{{cite news |title=Protesters Say Police in China Killed Up to 20 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/10/world/asia/protesters-say-police-in-china-killed-up-to-20.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=10 December 2005 |accessdate=6 December 2015}}</ref>
The village was sealed off by government forces who are searching for suspects involved in the violence and preventing people from leaving the village.{{update inline|?=yes|date=December 2015}}
==Casualties== The official New China News Agency stated that three people had been killed and eight others injured, but there are other reports that quoted villagers saying as many as 20 people had been killed.
There are reports that local authorities are refusing to return bodies to families, in some cases offering money to villagers instead so that they would stop asking for the bodies. It is also reported that on 9 December, many villagers held incense sticks and knelt in front of police barricades in the village, asking for the bodies of their loved ones for proper burial. They have so far been refused. The ''[[South China Morning Post]]'' quoted some residents who said that the officials were attempting to hide the death toll. {{ref|QuoteHideDeathToll}}
==Aftermath== On 11 December 2005, the Chinese government announced that a police commander was detained for mishandling the protest and causing deaths and injuries.{{ref|commanderDetained}} ''[[Ta Kung Pao]]'' reported on 13 December that, according to the Shanwei TV Station via [[Agence France Presse]], Wu Sheng, the vice director of the Shanwei Police Department, was placed in criminal detention by procurator bureau for mishandling the event.<ref>[http://www.takungpao.com/news/05/12/13/ZM-496758.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051215083413/http://www.takungpao.com/news/05/12/13/ZM-496758.htm |date=15 December 2005 }}</ref> According to local television via ''[[The Washington Post]]'', nine residents were also arrested.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/12/13/AR2005121302007.html |title=China Wavers on Police Shooting |publisher=Washingtonpost.com |date= 14 December 2005|accessdate=2013-07-28 |first=Philip P. |last=Pan}}</ref>
So far, {{Update|date=December 2015}} the news has been followed closely by Hong Kong, Taiwan, dissident Chinese, and overseas media, but has received lesser coverage in [[mainland China]] media.
In June 2006, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that 19 villagers had been prosecuted for the unrest, 7 being given long sentences for disturbing public order and using explosives against the Police. This was taken to be evidence of the Chinese government covering up the true nature of the shootings. The trial was not widely reported on and locals said that they were constantly being pressured not to talk about what happened in 2005. Construction work resumed on the plant after the protests ended, with no compensation being handed out. No public investigation of the shootings has been carried out either.
In November 2006, the [[BBC]] reported that tension was again mounting in Dongzhou. The report stated that residents had taken eight local officials hostage after a villager was detained.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/6157632.stm |title=Tense standoff in China village, BBC, 17 November, 2006 |publisher=BBC News |date=2006-11-19 |accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref> Two days later, [[Radio Free Asia]] reported that the officials had been released following a dawn raid by police, but more villagers had been detained.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/social/2006/11/19/china_shanwei |title=News Blackout in Dongzhou as Clampdown Continues, RFA, 19 November, 2006 |publisher=Rfa.org |date= |accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref> Shortly after, a similar event took place at another village in Guangdong, where villagers attempted to detain officials in a dispute over compensation for loss of farm land.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/2006/11/30/china_hostages |title=Villagers Detained, Hostages Released in South China Land Clash, RFA, 30 November, 2006 |publisher=Rfa.org |date=2013-06-02 |accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref> Clearly the events in Dongzhou are not an isolated case but part of an ongoing wave of protests against land grabs in China,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A6968-2004Oct4.html |title=China's Land Grabs Raise Specter of Popular Unrest, Washington Post, 5 Oct 2004 |publisher=Washingtonpost.com |date=2004-10-05 |accessdate=2013-07-28 |first=Edward |last=Cody}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/6135156.stm |title=China village fury at land grab, BBC Online, 10 Nov 2006 |publisher=BBC News |date=2006-11-10 |accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref> which Prime Minister [[Wen Jiabao]] has acknowledged is an "historic error".<ref>{{cite web|last=Saltzstein |first=Dan |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/01/20/news/china.php |title=In China, a warning on illegal land grabs, International Herald Tribune, 20 January, 2006 |publisher=International Herald Tribune |date= |accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Human rights in the People's Republic of China]] * [[Siege of Wukan]] (2011), some 25 km to the northeast * [[Tangshan Protest]]
==References== {{Wikinews|Protesting Chinese villagers killed in confrontation with police}} *{{Cite news| url = http://www.iht.com/articles/2005/12/09/news/china.php | work= International Herald Tribune |title = Chinese protesters report a massacre | date=9 December 2005}} *{{Cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/4507130.stm |work = BBC News | title= Chinese police 'shoot protesters' | date = 7 December 2005}} *{{Cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/4517706.stm | work = BBC News | title = China official held over shooting | date = 11 December 2005}} *{{Cite news | title = Police commander detained after deadly protest| url = http://msnbc.msn.com/id/10402725/ | work = MSNBC | date = 11 December 2005}} *[http://www.ifex.org/en/content/view/full/71219/ "Beijing imposes news blackout on Dongzhou shootings"] – ''IFEX'', 20 December 2005. *[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/27/world/27china.html "China Covers Up Violent Suppression of Village Protest"] - ''The New York Times'', 27 June 2006

{{Infobox school |name = Galil Jewish-Arab School |native_name = {{Hebrew|'''בית ספר גליל– דו לשוני'''}}
مدرسة الجليل - ثنائية اللغة |logo = |image = Galileeschool-exterior.jpg |image size = 270px |location = Eshbal |region = Galilee |country = Israel |religious_affiliation = Jewish-Muslim-Christian |established = c. 1998 |principal = Kamal Abu Yunis |grades = 1-9 |students = 200 |language = Bilingual Hebrew and Arabic |url = {{URL|http://yad.sisma.org.il/school/galil/Pages/Default.aspx}} }} '''Galil Jewish–Arab School''' is the first joint [[Arab]]-[[Jew]]ish [[Primary education|primary school]] in [[Israel]], founded in 1998. It is located on land owned by [[kibbutz]] [[Eshbal]], in the [[Misgav Regional Council|Misgav]] district of the [[Galilee]], near the [[Arab]] town of [[Sakhnin]]. [[Image:GalilSchoolSign.jpg|thumb|250px|left|The sign outside Galil School.]] ==History== The Galil Jewish-Arab school was established in 1998 by the [[Hand in Hand: Center for Jewish Arab Education in Israel]], which also runs other bilingual schools in Israel. In 2007, the school had a student body of 200 Jewish and Arab students ([[Jews]], [[Muslims]] and [[Christians]]) in Grades 1-9. The students live in [[Sakhnin]], [[Sha'ab, Israel|Sha’ab]], and communities of the [[Misgav Regional Council]], whose populations have expressed support for bilingual, multicultural education. ==Educational model== As in all Hand in Hand schools, Galil School strives to maintain an equal number of Arab and Jewish students; each class has two teachers, one Arab and one Jewish, the school has two co-principals, Arab and Jewish (currently Tagreed Hatib and Orna Eylat). Hand in Hand's approach to [[bilingual education]] aims to create equality, understanding, and coexistence between the Arab and Jewish populations of Israel, who often live segregated from one another. Classes at Hand in Hand schools are co-taught by an Arab and Jewish teacher, each teaching in his or her native language. Teachers do not translate, providing a strong incentive for students to attain fluency in the second language.[http://www.iht.com/articles/2003/02/18/risrael_ed3_.php Judith Sudilovsky, "INTERNATIONAL EDUCATION/ A SPECIAL REPORT: Building bridges in Israel," ''International Herald Tribune'' (Paris), February 18, 2003.] The school exposes the students to all three cultures and demonstrates the principles of [[democracy]] and [[social equality]] in a straightforward and practical way. ==See also== *[[Arab-Israeli peace projects]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Galil Jewish–Arab School}} *[http://www.handinhandk12.org/inform/schools/galilee About the school on the "Hand in Hand" web site] *[http://www.slideshare.net/galilschoolparents/galil-english-presentation-short?src=apiembed A slideshow presentation about the school] {{DEFAULTSORT:Galil Jewish-Arab School}} [[Category:1998 establishments in Israel]] [[Category:Charities based in Israel]] [[Category:Israeli–Palestinian peace process]] [[Category:Non-governmental organizations involved in the Israeli–Palestinian peace process]] [[Category:Peace organizations]] [[Category:Schools in Israel]]

{{Infobox Indian political party |party_name = Gujarat Parivartan Party |logo =[[File:Gujarat Pari Party logo 2013-12-13 01-03.JPG]] |colorcode = yellow |leader = [[Keshubhai Patel]] (founder)
[[Gordhan Zadafia]] (president) |general_secretary = |foundation =6 August 2012 |dissolution =24 February 2014 |headquarters = [[Ahmedabad]], Gujarat |publication = |students = |merged_with=[[Bharatiya Janata Party]] |youth = |women = |labour = |ideology = |international = |colours = yellow |symbol = cricket bat |website = }} '''Gujarat Parivartan Party''' was a political party from [[Gujarat]], [[India]]. It was founded by [[Keshubhai Patel]] in August 2012. It performed poorly in 2012 assembly elections. Later it was merged with [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] (BJP) in February 2014. ==Formation== GPP was founded by former [[Chief Minister of Gujarat]] Keshubhai Patel on 6 August 2012. [[Gordhan Zadafia]] led Mahagujarat Janata Party dissolved itself in the Gujarat Parivartan Party.{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/keshubhai-patel-formally-launches-gujarat-parivartan-party-251850 |title=Keshubhai Patel formally launches Gujarat Parivartan Party |publisher=NDTV.com |date=2012-08-06 |accessdate=2012-10-27}} ==2012 Gujarat legislative assembly elections== Gujarat Parivartan Party performed poorly and won two seats in [[Gujarat legislative assembly election, 2012]].{{cite news|last=Samay|first=Live|title=Gujarat Assembly elections 2012 results: Winners list|url=http://english.samaylive.com/nation-news/politics-news/676520483/gujarat-assembly-elections-2012-results-winners-list.html|accessdate=22 December 2012|newspaper=samaylive.com|date=December 20, 2012}} # Keshubhai Patel - [[Visavadar]] constituency # Nalin Kotadiya - [[Dhari, Gujarat|Dhari]] constituency == Merger with BJP == GPP MLA [[Keshubhai Patel]] resigned in February following his ill health in early February 2014.{{cite news|url=http://m.timesofindia.com/india/Keshubhai-resigns-as-MLA/articleshow/30369234.cms|title=Keshubhai resigns as MLA|date=2014-02-14|accessdate=2014-02-17|publisher=The Times of India}} President of GPP [[Gordhan Zadafia]] announced merger of GPP with the [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] (BJP) on 24 February 2014. Senior leader of GPP and former chief minister [[Suresh Mehta]] opposed the decision. Nalin Kotadiya who represented Dhari in the [[Gujarat Legislative Assembly]] joined BJP along with party.{{cite web |url=http://www.niticentral.com/2014/02/25/gujarat-parivartan-party-merges-with-bjp-193319.html |title=Gujarat Parivartan Party merges with BJP |publisher=Niticentral |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306013347/http://www.niticentral.com/2014/02/25/gujarat-parivartan-party-merges-with-bjp-193319.html |archivedate=2014-03-06 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://post.jagran.com/keshubhai-patels-gujarat-parivartan-party-merges-with-bjp-1393300118 |title=Keshubhai Patel’s Gujarat Parivartan Party merges with BJP |publisher=Jagran}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.gujaratparivartanparty.in Official website] [[Category:Bharatiya Janata Party breakaway groups]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Gujarat]] {{India-party-stub}}

The '''Gypsy International Recognition and Compensation Action''' is a [[human rights]] organization seeking justice on behalf of the [[Romani people]] (Gypsies) for the crimes of the [[Porajmos]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Fomerand|first=Jacques|title=Historical Dictionary of Human Rights|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0qLmAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA293|date=18 February 2014|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=978-0-8108-8035-1|page=293}}</ref>
In 2002, it filed suit against [[IBM]] for IBM's involvement with [[Nazism|Nazi]] [[war crime]]s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/Technology/Swiss-high-court-rejects-Gypsy-Holocaust-suit-versus-IBM-cites-time-limit/2006/08/19/1155408031630.html|title=Swiss high court rejects Gypsy Holocaust suit versus IBM, cites time limit|date=August 19, 2006|accessdate=April 13, 2010|publisher=The [[Sydney Morning Herald]]}}</ref> The suit was filed after author [[Edwin Black]] provided documentation in his book ''[[IBM and the Holocaust]]'' that IBM machines were tailored for the Nazis to track their victims, including [[Romani people|Gypsies]].
In 2006, the Swiss Supreme Court judges dismissed the lawsuit because too much time had elapsed.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.internationalcrimesdatabase.org/Case/1022/GIRCA-v-IBM/ | title=Gypsy International Recognition and Compensation Action (GIRCA) v. International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) | publisher=International Crimes Database | accessdate=28 December 2014}}</ref> An earlier Swiss court said the charges against IBM were likely to be sustained.
==See also == *[[Environmental racism in Europe]]
