{{Politics of Madagascar}} '''Human rights in [[Madagascar]]''' are protected under the country's [[constitution]]. However the extent to which such rights are reflected in practice, is subject to debate. The 2009 Human Rights Report by the [[United States Department of State]] noted concerns regarding the suspension of democratic electoral processes as the result of recent political unrest.<ref name="2009 Human Rights Report">, [https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/af/135962.htm 2009 U.S Dept of State Human Rights Report: Madagascar]</ref> Furthermore, reports of [[Political corruption|corruption]], arbitrary arrest and [[child labor]] highlight the prevalence of human rights issues in the country.<ref name="2009 Human Rights Report" /><ref>Lawson H, Bertucci M.L, ''Encyclopedia of human rights'', Taylor & Francis, 1996. p.978</ref>
==Constitution and statutory responses== {{update|the constitution - new constitution has been adopted|date=April 2013}} Adopted in 1992, the [[Constitution of Madagascar]] addresses the notion of [[universal suffrage]], individual rights and the [[freedom of speech]].<ref name=cs>{{csref|country=madagascar|author=Peter J. Schraeder|section=Constitution and Institutions of Governance}}</ref>
Laws regarding a minimum age for employment as well as the prohibition of child labor were passed.<ref name="2009 Human Rights Report" />
==International treaties== Madagascar's stances on [[International human rights law|international human rights treaties]] are as follows:
{| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="border:none; " !International treaties |- |style="padding:0; border:none;"| {| class="wikitable sortable" width=100% style="border-collapse:collapse;" |- style="background:#eee; font-weight:bold; text-align:center;" | Treaty | Organization | Introduced | Signed | Ratified |- align=center | style="background:#99f; align=left" | [[Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide]]<ref name='UN 1'> {{cite web|url=http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=IV-1&chapter=4&lang=en |title=United Nations Treaty Collection: Chapter IV: Human Rights: 1. Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide. Paris, 9 December 1948 |accessdate=2012-08-29 |author=[[United Nations]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020233944/http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=IV-1&chapter=4&lang=en |archivedate=20 October 2012 |df= }}</ref> | style="background:#99f;" | [[United Nations]] | style="background:#99f;" |1948 | style="background:#99f;" |- | style="background:#99f;" |- |- align=center | style="background:#9f9; align=left" | [[International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination]]<ref name='UN 2'> {{cite web|url=http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=IV-2&chapter=4&lang=en |title=United Nations Treaty Collection: Chapter IV: Human Rights: 2. International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. ==Issues== ===Censorship=== Accusations of media [[censorship]] have risen due to the alleged restrictions on the coverage of government opposition.<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/200904230849.html ''Madagascar: Media Under Attack One Month After New President Installed'', allafrica.com]</ref> During the leadership conflict, Ravalomanana ordered the closure of "Viva TV", which was owned by his opponent, Rajoelina.<ref name="2009 Human Rights Report" />
===Equality=== Women's suffrage was officially recognized in 1959.<ref>[http://www.ipu.org/wmn-e/suffrage.htm ''Women's Suffrage'', ipu.org]</ref> However [[violence against women]] and [[human trafficking]] continues to be an issue in society.<ref name="2009 Human Rights Report" />
===Legal system=== The existence of key legal principles such as the [[rule of law]] and [[due process]], is in question due to the increase in arbitrary and politically motivated arrests in the after In December 2014, the ''[[List of Goods Produced by Child Labor or Forced Labor]]'' indicated that children in Madagascar engaged in 3 activities namely vanilla production, stone quarrying, and sapphire mining.
===Poverty=== The people of [[Madagascar]] are inherently oppressed by extreme levels and rates of [[poverty]]. As of 2005, the Eastern coast of the country had astoundingly high poverty rates of around 80% while urban areas are just over 50%. <ref>[http://sk8es4mc2l.search.serialssolutions.com/?sid=sersol&SS_jc=TC0001486750&title=Republic%20of%20Madagascar%3A%20Poverty%20Reduction%20Strategy%20Paper%20Annual%20Progress%20Report ''Republic of Madagascar: Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper Annual Progress Report 2005'']</ref> Over 80% of the population lived on under $1.25 per day and over 90% of the population on under $2.00 per day as of 2010. The country has seen major improvements in [[literacy]] rates. Generally, a correlation exists between literacy rates and poverty. Should the progress in increasing the number of literate Madagascans continue, poverty rates should begin to decline respectively. <ref>[https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/bitstream/handle/10986/18250/781310PRIORITY0English0Apr900May012.pdf?sequence=5&isAllowed=y ''Face of Poverty in Madagascar'']</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = John Garang de Mabior | image = [[File:John Garang.jpg|180px]] | office1 = [[List of Presidents of South Sudan|President of Southern Sudan]] | term_start1 = 9 July 2005 | term_end1 = 30 July 2005 | vicepresident1 = [[Salva Kiir Mayardit]] | predecessor1 = Position Created | successor1 = [[Salva Kiir Mayardit]] | office2 = [[Vice President of Sudan|First Vice President of Sudan]] | president2 = [[Omar al-Bashir]] | term_start2 = 9 January 2005 | term_end2 = 30 July 2005 | predecessor2 = [[Ali Osman Taha]] | successor2 = [[Salva Kiir Mayardit]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1945|6|23}} | birth_place = Wangulei village, [[Twic]], [[Anglo-Egyptian Sudan|Sudan]]
{{small|(now [[South Sudan]])}} | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2005|7|30|1945|6|23}} | death_place = [[New Cush]], [[Sudan]] | nationality = South Sudanese | spouse = [[Rebecca Nyandeng De Mabior]] | party = [[Sudan People's Liberation Movement]] | religion = [[Christianity]] | alma_mater = [[Grinnell College]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])}}
[[Iowa State University]] {{small|([[PhDs|PhD]])}} }} '''John Garang de Mabior''' (June 23, 1945 – July 30, 2005) was a Sudanese politician and [[revolutionary]] leader. From 1983 to 2005, he led the [[Sudan People's Liberation Army]] during the [[Second Sudanese Civil War]], and following a peace agreement he briefly served as [[Vice President of Sudan|First Vice President of Sudan]] from July 9, 2005 http://en.people.cn/200507/10/eng20050710_195278.html until his death in a helicopter crash on July 30, 2005. A [[Developmental economics|developmental economist]] by profession, Dr. Garang was a major influence on the movement that led to the foundation of South Sudan. ==Early life and education== A member of the [[Dinka people|Dinka]] ethnic group,{{Cite book|title = Omar Al-Bashir and Africa's Longest War|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=PT-uCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA62&lpg=PA62&dq=John+Garang+a+young+officer+from+Twic+Dinka&source=bl&ots=j7fPd0T1c6&sig=lXIUPTugim3sZdyZL1zsa7q4nTA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCwQ6AEwA2oVChMI6Mr9zabyxwIVzoCSCh320gr_#v=onepage&q=John%2520Garang%2520a%2520young%2520officer%2520from%2520Twic%2520Dinka&f=false|publisher = Pen and Sword|date = 2015-04-30|isbn = 9781473828230|first = Paul|last = Moorcraft}} Garang was born into a poor family in Wangulei village Twic East County in the upper Nile region of Sudan. An orphan by the age of ten, he had his fees for school paid by a relative, going to schools in [[Wau, Sudan|Wau]] and then [[Rumbek]]. In 1962 he joined the [[First Sudanese Civil War|first Sudanese civil war]], but because he was so young, the leaders encouraged him and others his age to seek an education. Because of the ongoing fighting, Garang was forced to complete his secondary education in [[Tanzania]]. After winning a scholarship, he went on to earn a Bachelor of Arts degree in Economics in 1969 from [[Grinnell College]] in [[Iowa]], United States.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/02/world/africa/leaders-call-death-of-former-rebel-leader-a-great-loss-to-sudan.html|title=Leaders call death of former rebel leader a great loss to Sudan|last=|first=|date=2005-08-02|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-11-19|language=en}} He was offered another scholarship to pursue graduate studies at the [[University of California, Berkeley]], but chose to return to Tanzania and study East African [[agricultural economics]] as a [[Thomas J. Watson Fellow]] at the [[University of Dar es Salaam]] (UDSM). At UDSM, he was a member of the [[University Students' African Revolutionary Front]]. However, Garang soon decided to return to Sudan and join the rebels.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}}. There is much erroneous reporting that Garang met and befriended [[Yoweri Museveni]], future president of Uganda, at this time; while both Garang and Museveni were students at UDSM in the 1960s, they did not attend at the same time.{{cite book|last=Prunier|first=Gérard|authorlink=Gérard Prunier|year=2009|title=Africa's World War: Congo, the Rwandan Genocide, and the Making of a Continental Catastrophe|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|location=Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-537420-9}}, p. 80. In 1970, Garang was among one of the batches of [[Gordon Muortat Mayen]]'s soldiers, the then leader of the Anyanya liberation movement, sent to Israel for military training. The civil war ended with the [[Addis Ababa Agreement (1972)|Addis Ababa Agreement]] of 1972 and Garang, like many rebels, was absorbed into the Sudanese military. For eleven years, he was a career soldier and rose from the rank of [[Captain (land and air)|captain]] to [[colonel]] after taking the [[United States Army Infantry School|Infantry Officers Advanced Course]] at [[Fort Benning]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], United States. During this period he took four years academic leave and received a Master's degree in [[agricultural economics]] from Iowa State University (ISU).{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}} In 1981, he earned a PhD in Economics from [[Iowa State University]] (ISU).{{Cite web|url=https://www.isualum.org/s/565/17/interior.aspx?sid=565&gid=1&pgid=2635&cid=3570&ecid=3570&ciid=7208&crid=0|title=A Voice for South Sudan|last=|first=|date=|website=Iowa State University Alumni Association|publisher=Iowa State University (ISU)|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-19}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?iframe&page=imprimable&id_article=23101|title=Sudanese students commemorate Garand death in US Iowa|last=Miller|first=Tim|date=2007-07-31|website=Sudan Tribune News|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-19}} By 1983, Col. Garang was serving as a senior instructor in the military academy in Wadi Sayedna 21 km from the centre of [[Omdurman]] where he instructed the cadets for more than four years. Later he was nominated to serve in the military research department at Army HQ in [[Khartoum]]. == Political ideology == Dr. Garang coined the philosophy of ‘[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GfnhnDeUgpQ&t=2046s Sudanism]’ which would be the guiding philosophy to a secular and multiethnic [[New Sudan]]{{cite web|website=[[YouTube]] |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7F4GPSZP0Fc |title=What is the government in view of Dr. John Garang|publisher=Sudanese Online |date=2012-03-27 |accessdate=2018-10-04}}. He believed, for the people of Sudan to live in cohesion, they must not separate themselves into the many existing ethnic factions present within the nation but, rather, to collectively renounce the belief that Arabness, Black African-ness, Islam or Christianity were to be the ultimate defining characteristics of Sudan. Rather, he willed that citizens should embrace all cultures of Sudan, and to unify under the one commonality they all share, being Sudanese. ==Rebel leader== In 1983, Garang went to [[Bor town, Sudan|Bor]], ostensibly to pacify 500 southern government soldiers in Battalion 105 who were resisting being rotated to posts in the north. However, Garang was already part of a conspiracy among some officers in the Southern Command arranging for the defection of Battalion 105 to the anti-government rebels. When the government attacked Bor in May and the battalion pulled out, Garang rode by an alternate route to join them in the rebel stronghold in Ethiopia. By the end of July, Garang had brought over 3000 rebel soldiers under his control through the newly created [[Sudan People's Liberation Army]]/Movement (SPLA/M), which was opposed to military rule and Islamic dominance of the country, and encouraged other army garrisons to mutiny against the [[Sharia|Islamic law]] imposed on the country by the government.[[Douglas H. Johnson|Johnson, D.]] ''The Root Causes of Sudan's Civil Wars'', Indiana University Press, 2003, pp. 61–2. This action marked the commonly agreed upon the beginning of the [[Second Sudanese Civil War]], which resulted in one and a half million deaths over twenty years of conflict. Although Garang was Christian and most of southern Sudan is non-Muslim (mostly [[animist]]), he did not initially focus on the religious aspects of the war. [[File:John Garang of Sudan.jpg|thumb|John Garang of Sudan]] Garang had been fighting for a "New Sudan" since 1983. He was a strong advocate for national unity: minorities together formed a majority and therefore should rule. Together, Garang believed, they could replace President [[Omar al-Bashir]] with a government made up of representatives from “all tribes and religions in Sudan." His first real effort for the cause, under his command, occurred in July 1985 with the SPLA’s incursion into Kordofan.Cockett, R., 2010, Sudan: Darfur and the Failure of an African State, Yale UP. The SPLA gained the backing of Libya, Uganda, and Ethiopia. Garang and his army controlled a large part of the southern regions of the country, named ''New Sudan''. He claimed his troops' courage came from "the conviction that we are fighting a just cause. That is something North Sudan and its people don't have." Critics suggested financial motivations to his rebellion, noting that much of Sudan's [[Petroleum|oil]] wealth lies in the south of the country. In the spring of 1991, [[Mengistu Haile Mariam]]'s regime (in Ethiopia) was overthrown by the Khartoum backed Ethiopian rebels ([[Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front]]). Upon the rebels’ seizure of the government, they closed all SPLA training camps in Ethiopia and cut off the SPLA's arms supply, forcing the SPLA to return hundreds of thousands of Sudanese back to [[South Sudan]]. This disrupted military operations and leadership within the SPLA. However, this caused the West to reconsider relations with the SPLA – justifying their providing the SPLA with "non-lethal help."Flint, J. and Alex de Waal, 2008 (2nd Edn), Darfur: A New History of a Long War, Zed Books. Shortly after, there was an attempted coup to oust Garang by senior SPLA commanders, [[Riek Machar]] and [[Lam Akol]], in August 1991. The splinter group led by Machar and Akol was named the [[SPLA-Nasir]]. The coup turned out to be premature – however, it did expose the deep ethnic divides within the SPLA. The Southern Sudanese communities became more divided than ever before in their history. These organic divides among the Southern Sudanese communities were exacerbated by the deliberate "divide and rule" policies instituted by the regimes in Khartoum, in order to maintain their power over the Southern Sudanese peoples. [[Image:John Garang in crowd.jpg|thumb|left|Garang in a crowd of supporters]] Garang refused to participate in the 1985 interim government or the 1986 elections, remaining a rebel leader. However, the SPLA and government signed a peace agreement on January 9, 2005, in [[Nairobi]], in Kenya. On July 9, 2005, he was sworn in as the First-Vice-President - the second most powerful person in the country - following a ceremony in which he and President [[Omar al-Bashir]] signed a power-sharing constitution. Simultaneously, he became the premier in southern Sudan. This administration had limited autonomy for six years, at the end of which there would be a scheduled referendum regarding secession. No Christian or southerner had ever held such a high government post. Commenting after this ceremony, Garang stated, "I congratulate the Sudanese people, this is not my peace or the peace of al-Bashir, it is the peace of the Sudanese people." In the Hillcrest Hotel in [[Nairobi]] on New Year's Day 2003, there was a meeting between the SPLA and the [[Fur people]]. Garang asked two associates of [[Abdul Wahid al Nur]] (who later formed the [[Sudan Liberation Movement]]) to declare that the [[Fur people]] were with the SPLA – they refused. Over 15 months, starting in September 2003, [[Ali Osman]] and Garang met in private in [[Naivasha]]. Their secret meetings and negotiations lasted up until the [[Comprehensive Peace Agreement]] (CPA) was initialed on New Year's Eve 2004. The CPA appeared to embody the vision of the "New Sudan" that Garang wanted. Within the CPA, power was split between the [[National Congress (Sudan)|National Congress Party]] and the [[Sudan People's Liberation Movement]] for six years, until 2010, with Garang as the first vice-president. As a leader, John Garang's democratic credentials were often questioned. For example, according to Gill Lusk, "John Garang did not tolerate dissent and anyone who disagreed with him was either imprisoned or killed".{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/2134220.stm|title=Obituary: John Garang|last=Phombeah|first=Gray|date=2005-08-03|website=BBC News|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2018-11-18}} Under his leadership, the SPLA was accused of human rights abuses. The ideological profile of SPLA was as shadowy as Garang himself. He varied from Marxism to drawing support from Christian fundamentalists in the US. The [[United States State Department]] argued that Garang's presence in the government would have helped solve the [[Darfur conflict]] in western Sudan, but others consider these claims "excessively optimistic".{{cite web | title= Untimely Death| author=Reeves, Eric | work=[[The New Republic]] | url=http://www.tnr.com/doc.mhtml?i=w050801&s=reeves080205 | date=2005-08-02}} U.S. President [[George W. Bush]], who supported South Sudanese independence, especially considered Garang to be a promising leader and called him a "partner in peace."{{cite web|title=Number of Sudan peacekeepers might need to be doubled, Bush says|url=http://reliefweb.int/report/sudan/number-sudan-peacekeepers-might-need-be-doubled-bush-says|accessdate=1 April 2015}} Bush highlighted Garang's Christian faith, and even connected him to support at evangelical churches in his hometown of [[Midland, Texas]].{{cite web|last1=McDonnell|first1=Nick|title=The Activist Alex de Waal among the war criminals|url=http://harpers.org/archive/2008/11/the-activist/4/|publisher=Harpers|accessdate=1 April 2015}} ==Death== In late July 2005, Garang died after the Ugandan presidential [[Mil Mi-17|Mi-172]] helicopter he was flying in crashed. He had been returning from a meeting in [[Rwakitura]] with long-time ally President [[Yoweri Museveni]] of Uganda. He did not tell the Sudanese government that he was going to this meeting and therefore did not take the presidential plane. In fact, Garang had said he was going to spend the weekend in [[New Kush|New Cush]], a small village near the Kenyan borders founded by Garang himself. To this day neither the identity of any other participants at the meeting nor its purpose, are known. After the helicopter had been missing for more than 24 hours, the Ugandan president notified the Sudanese government, which in turn contacted the SPLM for information. The SPLM responded that the helicopter Garang was taking had landed safely on an old SPLA training camp. The Sudanese state television duly reported this. A few hours later, Abdel Basset Sabdarat, Sudan's Information Minister, then appeared on TV to refute the earlier report that Garang's helicopter landed safely. It was, in fact, Yasir Arman, the SPLA/M spokesperson, who had told the government that Garang's plane had landed safely and his intention, in doing so, was to buy time for internal succession arrangements within the SPLA, before Garang's death was to be declared. Garang's plane crashed on Friday and he remained 'missing' throughout Saturday. During this time, the government believed he was still resolving his affairs in Southern Sudan. Finally, a statement released by the office of the Sudanese President, [[Omar Hasan Ahmad al-Bashir|Omar el-Bashir]], confirmed that the Ugandan presidential helicopter had crashed into ''"a mountain range in southern Sudan because of poor visibility and this resulted in the death of Dr. John Garang DeMabior, six of his colleagues and seven Ugandan crew members".''https://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/ap/20050801/ap_on_re_mi_ea/sudan_plane_missing According to the Sudan Tribune John Garang's legacy was a major cornerstone in Sudan's fight for independence. Without Garang, many marginalized people of Africa, including that of Sudan would still be largely forgotten about in the modern world. [[File:Sudan Juba grave of John Garang 17jun2006.jpg|thumb|Grave of John Garang in [[Juba]], [[South Sudan]] - guarded by [[Sudan People's Liberation Army|SPLA]]-soldiers]] His body was flown to New Cush, a southern Sudanese settlement near the scene of the crash, where former rebel fighters and civilian supporters gathered to pay their respects to Garang. Garang's funeral took place on August 3 in [[Juba, Sudan|Juba]].{{cite news | title=Sudan bids rebel leader farewell |work=BBC News | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/4126370.stm | date=2005-08-06}} His widow, [[Rebecca Nyandeng De Mabior]], promised to continue his work stating: ''In our culture we say "if you kill the lion, you see what the lioness will do".''{{cite web | title= Widow of Sudan's Garang Steps In to Continue His Mission| author=Wax, Emily | work=[[The Washington Post]] | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/08/29/AR2005082901861_pf.html | date=2005-08-30 | accessdate=2007-04-25}} ===Rumors=== Both the Sudanese government and the head of the SPLA blamed the weather for the accident. There are, however, doubts as to whether this was the true cause, especially among the rank and file of the SPLA. Yoweri Museveni, the Ugandan President, stated that the possibility of "external factors" having played a role could not be eliminated.{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} The SPLM/SPLA Rumbek crisis, which took place in Rumbek from November 29 to December 1, 2004; one month before the signing of the CPA is also believed to have been a factor relevant to Dr. John Garang's death. While the Sudanese people followed the Naivasha peace talks closely, with high hopes of freedom and democratic transformation, the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (SPLM) was rife with rumors and accusations of conspiracy relating to the removal of SPLM deputy Chairman, [[Salva Kiir Mayardit]], and his replacement with the young [[Nhial Deng Nhial]]. Nhial Deng Nhial was the son of the famous leader of the southern Sudanese, [[William Deng Nhial]], who had been assassinated by the Sudanese army in 1968. William Deng Nhial had led the [[Sudan African National Union]] (SANU) in exile, but had returned to Sudan to take part in the 1968 elections, shortly before he was killed. ==See also== *[[First Sudanese Civil War]] *[[Second Sudanese Civil War]] *[[Sudan People's Liberation Army]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} * ''Aufstand in der Dreistadt'' by Thomas Schimidinger in ''Jungle World'' Nr.32: August 10, 2005; ISSN 1613-0766 ==Publications== *Garang, John, 1987 ''John Garang Speaks''. M. Khalid, ed. London: Kegan Paul International. == External links == {{commons category}} *{{National Public Radio|4496451}} * {{Official website|http://www.splmtoday.com/}} of the [[Sudan People's Liberation Army]] *[https://www.state.gov/www/issues/relief/sudanproject.html A State Department archive] of information from before January 2001 * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4666701.stm Sudan ex-rebel {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2017}} {{More citations needed|date=October 2017}} This is a list of [[Prime Ministers of Canada]] by [[religion|religious]] affiliation. It notes party affiliation after the name. All Canadian Prime Ministers have affiliations with [[Christianity]].
In early Canadian history, religion played an important role in politics. The [[Conservative Party of Canada (historic)|Conservative Party]] was composed mainly of [[Anglicans]] and conservative [[French Canadian|French-Canadian]] [[Catholics]] while the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal Party]] was backed by reform-minded [[French Canadian]] Catholics and non-Anglican [[English Canadian]]s due to their support in [[Quebec]] and [[Ontario]]. In recent years, religion has played a background role in Canadian politics. Modern Prime Ministers have been reticent about discussing their faith.
==Roman Catholic (10 PMs, 18 mandates)== * [[John Sparrow David Thompson|Sir John Thompson]] (Conservative) (Born a [[Methodist]] but converted to Catholicism when he married.) * [[Wilfrid Laurier|Sir Wilfrid Laurier]] (Liberal) (Strongly [[anti-clerical]].) * [[Louis St. Laurent]] (Liberal) * [[Pierre Trudeau]] (Liberal) (Believer in Catholic [[Personalism]]. Former board member of the [[Humanist Canada|Humanist Fellowship of Montreal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://terahertzatheist.ca/2013/09/21/political-atheists/|title=Political Atheists|first=Ian|last=Bushfield|publisher=Terahertz|date=September 21, 2013|accessdate=October 27, 2017}}</ref>) * [[Joe Clark]] (Progressive Conservative) * [[John Napier Turner]] (Liberal) * [[Brian Mulroney]] (Progressive Conservative) * [[Jean Chrétien]] (Liberal) (Strongly anti-clerical in his youth.) * [[Paul Martin]] (Liberal) (Came into conflict with the [[Catholic Church]] over his support for the ''[[Civil Marriage Act]]'', by not allowed Cabinet ministers to have conscience votes.) * [[Justin Trudeau]] (Liberal) (Baptized and raised as a Catholic, became a [[lapsed Catholic]] in his youth until the death of his brother Michel. Mother was Anglican.)
==Anglican (4 PMs, 8 mandates)== * [[John A. Macdonald|Sir John A. Macdonald]] (Conservative) (Raised [[Presbyterian]], converted in 1875.) * [[John Joseph Caldwell Abbott|Sir John Abbott]] (Conservative) * [[Robert Borden|Sir Robert Borden]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?&id_nbr=7998 |title=Borden, Sir Robert Laird |work=Dictionary of Canadian Biography Online |publisher=Library and Archives Canada |first=Robert Craig |last=Brown |year=2004 |accessdate=December 7, 2006}}</ref> (Conservative) (Raised [[Presbyterian]].) * [[Kim Campbell]] (Progressive Conservative) (Does not attend church and criticizes the treatment of women by organized religion. In 2004 she stated that religion "gets in the way of morality".)<ref>{{cite book|title=The Politics of Kim Campbell: From School Trustee to Prime Minister|first=Murray|last=Dobbin|publisher=James Lorimer|year=1993|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-6qyKqoy_HEC}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kimcampbell.com/node/252|title=Morality vs Religion|year=2004|accessdate=October 27, 2017}}</ref>
==Presbyterian (3 PMs, 6 mandates)== * [[Mackenzie Bowell|Sir Mackenzie Bowell]] (Conservative) ([[Orange Institution|Orange Order]] leader) * [[Arthur Meighen]] (Conservative) (Became a major fundraiser for the [[Salvation Army]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?&id_nbr=7987 |title=Meighen, Arthur |work=Dictionary of Canadian Biography Online |publisher=Library and Archives Canada |first=Larry A. |last=Glassford |year=2004 |accessdate=December 7, 2006}}</ref>) * [[William Lyon Mackenzie King]] (Liberal) (Also a believer in various forms of [[mysticism]].)
==Baptist (3 PMs, 4 mandates)== * [[Alexander Mackenzie (politician)|Alexander Mackenzie]] (Liberal) * [[Charles Tupper|Sir Charles Tupper]] (Conservative) (Born a [[Baptist]], married an [[Anglican]] and attended that church with his family. On his own sometimes attended Baptist churches.) * [[John Diefenbaker]] (Progressive Conservative)
==United Church of Canada (2 PMs, 3 mandates)== * [[Richard Bedford Bennett]] (Conservative) (Was a [[Methodist]] before that denomination merged into the [[United Church of Canada]].) * [[Lester B. Pearson]] (Liberal) (Was a [[Methodist]] before that denomination merged into the [[United Church of Canada]].)
==Evangelical (1 PM, 3 mandates)== * [[Stephen Harper]]<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.macleans.ca/topstories/religion/article.jsp?content=20060220_121848_121848 |title=The church of Stephen Harper |journal=Macleans |first=Colin |last=Campbell |date=February 20, 2006 |accessdate=December 7, 2006 |format=| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061114214314/http://www.macleans.ca/topstories/religion/article.jsp?content=20060220_121848_121848| archivedate = November 14, 2006}}</ref> (Conservative) (Raised in the [[United Church of Canada]].<ref>[http://www.canadianchristianity.com/cgi-bin/na.cgi?nationalupdates/010820evangelink]</ref> Subsequently, joined [[Christian and Missionary Alliance]].)

{{Use British English|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Louise Burfitt-Dons | image = Louise Burfitt-Dons at Westminster.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Louise Olivian Byres | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1953|10|22}} | birth_place = [[Magwa|Magwa, Great Burgan, Kuwait]] | nationality = British | other_names = | known_for = Activism | occupation = Public speaker; author | spouse = {{Marriage|Donald Burfitt-Dons|1982}} | children = Brooke, Arabella | website = {{URL|www.louiseburfittdons.com}} }} '''Louise Burfitt-Dons''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|FRSA}} (née Byres; born 22 October 1953) is a British writer, humanitarian, and former [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] candidate.
Burfitt-Dons is best known for her [[Bullying#Anti-bullying movement|anti-bullying]] work as the founder of the charity [[Act Against Bullying]] and co-founder of [[Kindness Day UK]].
==Early years and family== Louise Olivian Byres was born to Olive and Ian Byres in a small desert hospital at Magwa, in the [[Great Burgan|Burgan]] district just south of Kuwait City. Her father worked for [[Kuwait Oil Company]] and her mother ran a kindergarten. She had an elder brother, Laurence. She attended the Anglo-American School in Kuwait, and later [[The Hertfordshire and Essex High School]] and [[Ashford School|the Ashford School for Girls]] in Kent. Burfitt-Dons' father died of cancer when she was 26. During his illness she obtained a [[liquor licence]] and took over the running of The White Horse in [[East Bergholt]] so she could care for him.{{clarify|date=November 2013}}{{citation needed|date=November 2013}}
Burfitt-Dons has two daughters, [[Brooke Burfitt]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Impact of extra tropic cyclones in Europe on Insurance Industry - Transcript of keynote speech by Donald Burfitt-Dons|publisher=The Global Warming Alliance|url=http://www.globalwarmingalliance.com/insurance_implications.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711101642/http://www.globalwarmingalliance.com/insurance_implications.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=11 July 2011|accessdate=1 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Brooke appeals for residents' votes to help get her to semi final|publisher=ChiswickW4.com|date=14 October 2009|url=http://www.chiswickw4.com/info/conceleb195.htm|accessdate=1 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=About Brooke Burfitt-Dons|publisher=brookeburfitt.com|url=http://www.brookeburfitt.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=49&Itemid=27|accessdate=19 April 2011}}</ref> and Arabella (b. 1992),<ref>{{cite web|title=Arabella Burfitt-Dons - University of Nottingham - Civil Engineering|publisher=Autodesk|url=http://students.autodesk.com/?nd=m_student_profile&account_id=1838282&return_nd=m_university_detail|accessdate=19 April 2011}}</ref> by her pilot husband Donald Burfitt-Dons, a New Zealander whom she met and married in London in 1982 while he was on an overseas basing with [[Qantas]]. The couple lived in Australia between 1982–93 where Louise worked as an actress and wrote plays for the Sydney stage. She co-starred in a dinner theatre show with [[Andrew Harwood (television host)|Andrew Harwood]] in 1988. She lives in [[Chiswick]], [[London]].<ref>{{cite web|title=RAF Air Squadron Trophy Competition|work=News|publisher=The Lady Eleanor Holles School|url=http://www.lehs.org.uk/srnews/RAF_Air_Squadron_Trophy_Competition.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150119173244/http://www.lehs.org.uk/srnews/RAF_Air_Squadron_Trophy_Competition.php|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 January 2015|accessdate=1 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title =About Brooke Burfitt-Dons|work=Bio|publisher=Brooke Burfitt-Dons|url=http://www.brookeburfittdons.com/index.php?view=article&catid=34%3Acelebinterviews&id=49%3Ahayley&format=pdf&option=com_content&Itemid=41|format=PDF|accessdate=1 June 2010}}</ref>
==Social Commentary== Louise has appeared on [[Sky News]], [[Good Morning America]], [[Channel Four News]], [[ITV News London]], [[ITN]], [[BBC Breakfast]] and Talk Radio Europe, [[BBC Surrey]] and [[BBC Sussex]], [[BBC Oxford]], [[LBC]], [[PM_(BBC_Radio_4)]] [[talkRADIO]] [[The World Tonight]]. She has written on social affairs and political issues for a range of blogs including [[Conservative Home]] and [[Conservative Way Forward]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.conwayfor.org/louise_burfitt_dons_why_it_s_time_for_a_moderate_form_of_feminism_to_assert_itself|title=Louise Burfitt-Dons: Why it’s time for a moderate form of feminism to assert itself|work=conwayfor.org|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> She is a regular news reviewer on the [[Ian Collins (radio presenter)]] show Roundtable on [[LBC]].
==Boosting Britain== In 2012, after visiting a range of different businesses,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hertsandessexobserver.co.uk/Business/Business-News/Campaigner-visits-Dunmow-business-30082012.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227224837/http://www.hertsandessexobserver.co.uk/Business/Business-News/Campaigner-visits-Dunmow-business-30082012.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=27 February 2014|title=Campaigner visits Dunmow business|date=30 August 2012|work=hertsandessexobserver.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> she set up an online initiative named 'Boosting Britain' to encourage and promote new ideas and companies which were helping Britain. It covered [[infrastructure]], [[defence industry]], education as well as [[motivational]] factors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boostingbritain.org/index.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=19 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140225174020/http://boostingbritain.org/index.htm |archivedate=25 February 2014 }}</ref><ref name="conservativehome.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativehome.com/platform/2014/02/from-louiseburfdons-to-boost-britains-quota-of-engineers-why-not-take-a-page-from-germanys-book.html|title=Louise Burfitt-Dons: To boost Britain’s quota of engineers, why not take a page from Germany’s book? - Conservative Home|work=conservativehome.com|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> She has suggested more honorary titles for engineers would help to bolster their image and help with the skills shortage<ref name="conservativehome.com"/> As of 2017, the website was unregistered and not connecting.
==Campaigning== Since setting up [[Act Against Bullying]], Burfitt-Dons has been outspoken on the ill-effects of [[tribalism]] in society as a speaker and writer. She has advocated that tribalism is on the increase and has been taking effect in all forms of modern society leading to social unrest. Feeling the need to express what the public was confiding in her she designed a range of campaigns to promote human dignity and individuality in modern society.
She designed the "Cool to Be Kind" Campaign in 2000; two years later she founded the National Decency Campaign in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eparenting.co.uk/parenting/nationaldecencycampaign.shtml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=13 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061010140128/http://www.eparenting.co.uk/parenting/nationaldecencycampaign.shtml |archivedate=10 October 2006 }}</ref> and, in 2006, the "Grade Not Degrade" campaign. ''[[The Scotsman]]'' quoted her as suggesting ''[[Celebrity Big Brother 5 (UK)|Celebrity Big Brother]]'' was legitimising the growing trend of bullying behaviour in classrooms around the country.<ref>{{cite web|author=Hello |url=http://news.scotsman.com/entertainment.cfm?id=116102007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070209012759/http://news.scotsman.com/entertainment.cfm?id=116102007 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=9 February 2007 |title=Violent soap operas and bullying behaviour on television shows harm children - The Scotsman |website=News.scotsman.com |date=2007-01-23 |accessdate=2016-06-17 |df= }}</ref> She spoke at the Conservative Women's Organisation Forum <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativewomen.org.uk/article.asp?art_id=63 |title=CWO News :: CWO Forum - Cyber Bullying |website=Conservativewomen.org.uk |date=2007-06-28 |accessdate=2016-06-17}}</ref> at the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] on [[cyber bullying]] claiming that today "children have to be as savvy as celebrities but without the pr support". In response to the growing trend of internet abuse she designed the CyberKind Campaign, which was launched on [[Remembrance Day]] (11 November) 2009.
Burfitt-Dons founded the [[UK Kindness Movement]] and co-founder of [[Kindness Day UK]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2010/11/12/kindness-day-uk-launches-13-november_n_7414126.html|title=Kindness Day UK Launches 13 November|date=12 November 2010|work=huffingtonpost.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.responsesource.com/releases/rel_display.php?relid=60351|title=Tens of Thousands take up Kindness Across the UK|work=responsesource.com|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> She appeared on [[BBC Breakfast]] on the first Kindness Day UK on 13 November 2010 alongside [[Kathy Lette]] who claimed that English people were condescending and unfriendly.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=70ymutgb1k0 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=12 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101222157/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=70ymutgb1k0 |archivedate=1 November 2013 }}</ref> In 2007 she began campaigning on global warming and has said that "climate change may be the ultimate issue that unites us all". {{citation needed|date=November 2013}}
==Awards== In 2006 she was nominated as an Angel Hero for [[The My Hero Project]]. In May 2009 she was invited to become a [[Fellow]] of the [[Royal Society of Arts]] in recognition of her work with children as well as to acknowledge her efforts as a campaigner and speaker on humanitarian and environmental issues. {{citation needed|date=November 2013}}
==Global warming== Burfitt-Dons co-founded the Global Warming Alliance which was set up in January 2006 to find solutions to the crisis. On 2 December 2008, she launched the Global Warming Hotspot <ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/globalwarminghotspot |title=Globalwarminghotspot : List of videos |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date= |accessdate=2016-06-17}}</ref> channel on [[YouTube]]. She spearheaded the international Hot Women Campaign,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecoearth.info/links/Air/Climate/Policy_Actors/Non-Governmental_Organizations/welcome.asp|title=EcoEarth.Info Environment Links: Air/Climate/Policy Actors/Non-Governmental Organizations|date=21 April 2012|publisher=|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120421213159/http://www.ecoearth.info/links/Air/Climate/Policy_Actors/Non-Governmental_Organizations/welcome.asp|archivedate=21 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> which encouraged women to become more active in [[climate change]] issues and reduce carbon emissions and significantly raised awareness of the differences between male and female thinking on the issues.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://world.edu/worldedu_posts/genders-climate-change-women-men-accept-global-warming |title=How the genders think about climate change: Women more likely than men to accept global warming - World leading higher education information and services |website=World.edu |date=2010-09-26 |accessdate=2016-06-17}}</ref> ''The Scotsman'' quoted Burfitt-Dons' claims that "the relentless rise in CO2 emissions is incrementally raising planetary temperatures, increasing water vapour in the atmosphere with a commensurate rise in rainfall, and ever stronger wind patterns randomly occurring across the globe."<ref>{{cite news|author=Craig Brown |url=http://www.scotsman.com/the-scotsman/environment/darling_buds_of_may_april_more_like_1_1962484 |title=Darling buds of May? April more like |newspaper=[[The Scotsman]] |date=2011-11-12 |accessdate=2016-06-17}}</ref>
==Feminism== Burfitt-Dons got involved with women's issues because of her charity work as a motivational speaker and mentor. In October 2009 she was part of the freshers feminist debate at [[Cambridge University]] <ref>[http://cambridgetab.co.uk/featured/currie-tikkad-off-2] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20131105231031/http://cambridgetab.co.uk/featured/currie-tikkad-off-2 |date=5 November 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cambridgetab.co.uk/columnists/standing-up-for-sisterhood |title=Archived copy |accessdate=20 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091101003448/http://cambridgetab.co.uk/columnists/standing-up-for-sisterhood/ |archivedate=1 November 2009 }}</ref> with ''[[Cosmopolitan Magazine]]'' editor Louise Court and [[Edwina Currie]]. Burfitt-Dons set up the [[Royal Society of Arts]]' Women's Speakers' Network whose mission is to "raise women's profile in society by greater involvement in public speaking". She chaired the launch event at the [[Institution of Mechanical Engineers]] on 9 November 2010 in a public debate entitled "The Great Female Debate: Do Women Speak Too much or too little?"<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://belsizeconservatives.yourcllr.com/2010/10/26/do-women-speak-too-much-or-too-little |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131105231052/http://belsizeconservatives.yourcllr.com/2010/10/26/do-women-speak-too-much-or-too-little |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-11-05 |title=Do Women Speak Too Much Or Too Little? |website=Belsizeconservatives.yourcllr.com |date=2010-10-26 |accessdate=2016-06-17}}</ref> She believes that some feminist groups have hijacked and radicalised the equality movement and has catalysed a debate around feminism calling on more gender realism via her blog The Common Sense Feminist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thecommonsensefeminist.wordpress.com|title=The Common Sense Feminist|work=wordpress.com|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativehome.com/platform/2014/01/from-motivatingwoman-right-wing-feminism.html|title=Louise Burfitt-Dons: The successes and failures of feminism - Conservative Home|work=conservativehome.com|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> Her work on feminism includes the book ''Moderating Feminism:The Past The Now and What Comes Next'' (2016).
==Politics== In September 2014 she was selected to fight the 2015 General Election for the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] in [[Nottingham North]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.conservatives.com/OurTeam/Prospective_Parliamentary_Candidates/Burfitt-Dons.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=1 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150119183632/https://www.conservatives.com/OurTeam/Prospective_Parliamentary_Candidates/Burfitt-Dons.aspx |archivedate=19 January 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://conservativehome.blogs.com/platform/2013/05/louise.html |title=Louise Burfitt-Dons: It’s time for the Tories to target a new type of female voter |website=Conservativehome.blogs.com |date=2013-05-30 |accessdate=2016-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hucknalldispatch.co.uk/news/local/mp-slams-govt-fail-on-employment-1-6907825|title=MP slams Govt fail on employment|work=hucknalldispatch.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Robinson|first1=Dan|title=Nottingham MP calls for 'unfair' tax on sixth form colleges to be scrapped to help Bilborough youngsters |url=http://www.nottinghampost.com/Nottingham-MP-calls-unfair-tax-sixth-form/story-26016610-detail/story.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221144018/http://www.nottinghampost.com/Nottingham-MP-calls-unfair-tax-sixth-form/story-26016610-detail/story.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2015-02-21|website=Nottingham Post}}</ref> She clashed with the incumbent MP [[Graham Allen (politician)|Graham Allen]] over his criticism of small businesses in Nottingham North<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cunningham|first1=Tim|title=Politicians Clash over Minimum Pay|url=http://www.hucknalldispatch.co.uk/news/local/politicians-clash-over-minimum-pay-1-7055838|website=Hucknall Today|accessdate=16 January 2015}}</ref> She has challenged [[Nottingham City Council]] over its Workplace Parking Levy policy as `short term thinking' at its worse and suggested it was a political decision rather than an economic one.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Burfitt-Dons|first1=Louise|title=Louise Burfitt-Dons: Is the WPL an economic or a political issue?|url=http://www.nottinghampost.com/Louise-Burfitt-Dons-WPL-economic-political-issue/story-26122053-detail/story.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402134421/http://www.nottinghampost.com/Louise-Burfitt-Dons-WPL-economic-political-issue/story-26122053-detail/story.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2 April 2015|website=Nottingham Post|publisher=Nottingham Post Online|accessdate=6 March 2015}}</ref> Nottingham was the first City Council to introduce a Workplace Parking Levy in the UK.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Burfitt-Dons|first1=Louise|title=Online Voting Is Not Secure Enough|url=http://www.nottinghampost.com/Louise-Burfitt-Dons-Online-voting-quick-easy/story-26290207-detail/story.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20150428215207/http://www.nottinghampost.com/Louise-Burfitt-Dons-Online-voting-quick-easy/story-26290207-detail/story.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=28 April 2015|website=Nottingham Post|publisher=Nottingham Post|accessdate=15 April 2015}}</ref>
==Controversy== In 1999, she criticised the treatment of an incident {{clarify|date=November 2013}} involving her daughter, Brooke, and [[Princess Beatrice of York]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Parr|first=Alexis|title=Princess Beatrice broke my tooth at school ... now I want £2,000|work =Mail on Sunday|publisher=Associated Newspapers|date=9 September 2006|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-404382/Princess-Beatrice-broke-tooth-school---I-want-2-000.html|accessdate=1 June 2010}}</ref>
==Publications, novels and plays== *''The Missing Activist'' (August 2018 )<ref>{{cite book|last1=Burfitt-Dons|first1=Louise|title=The Missing Activist|date=7 August 2018|publisher=New Century Digibooks|isbn=9780953852291}}</ref> *''Moderating Feminism'' (August 2016 )<ref>{{cite book|last1=Burfitt-Dons|first1=Louise|title=Moderating Feminism|date=29 July 2016|publisher=New Century Digibooks|isbn=9780953852277}}</ref> *''The Counsellor'' (October 2000)<ref>{{cite book|last=Byres|first=Louise|title=The Counsellor|year=2000|publisher=New Century|isbn=9780953852215}}</ref> *''Painkillers'' (June 2001)<ref>{{cite book|last=Byres|first=Louise|title=Painkillers|year=June 2001|publisher=New Century|isbn=978-0953852239}}</ref> *''Act Against Bullying'' (August 2002)<ref>{{cite book|last=Burfitt-Dons|first=Louise|title=Act Against Bullying|year=2002|publisher=New Century|isbn=978-0953852253}}</ref> *''A Christmas Riddle'' (June 2000)<ref>{{cite book|last=Byres|first=Louise|title=A Christmas Riddle|year=2000|publisher=New Century|isbn=978-0953852208}}</ref> *''Valentine Card'' (June 2001)<ref>{{cite book|last=Byres|first=Louise|title=The Valentine Card|year=2001|publisher=New Century|isbn=978-0953852222}}</ref> *''How to Catch A Man'' (September 1991)<ref>{{cite book|last=Byres|first=Louise|title=How to Catch A Man|year=1991|publisher=Ashley Books|isbn=978-0879493479}}</ref>

{{Infobox government agency |agency_name = Ministry of Culture |nativename = Ministria e Kulturës |type = Department |logo = File:Ministria e Kulturës.svg |logo_width = 150px |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = 1941 |preceding1 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Albania]] |headquarters = [[Tirana]] |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = [[Mirela Kumbaro]] ''([[Socialist Party of Albania|PS]])'' |minister1_pfo = Minister of Culture |chief1_name = |chief1_position = |child1_agency = |website = {{URL|http://kultura.gov.al/}} |footnotes = }} {{Politics of Albania}}
The '''Ministry of Culture''' ({{sq|Ministria e Kulturës}}) is a department of the [[Council of Ministers (Albania)|Albanian Government]] responsible for the implementation of government tourism, cultural affairs, youth and sports policy. The current minister is [[Mirela Kumbaro]] of the [[Rama II Cabinet]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mtkrs.altirana.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127035623/http://mtkrs.altirana.com/ |archivedate=2010-11-27 |df= }}</ref>
== History == Since the establishment of the institution, the Ministry of Culture has been reorganized by joining other departments or merging with other ministries, thus making its name change several times. This list reflects the changes made in years in pluralist history since 1992 as an institution:
* Ministry of Culture, Youth and Sports ''(Ministria e Kulturës, Rinisë dhe Sporteve)'' form 1992 to 1996 * Ministry of Culture, Youth and Women ''(Ministria e Kulturës, Rinisë dhe Gruas)'' from 1996 to 1997 * Ministry of Culture, Youth and Sports ''(Ministria e Kulturës, Rinisë dhe Sporteve)'' form 1997 to 2005 * Ministry of Tourism, Culture, Youth and Sports ''(Ministria e Turizmit, Kulturës, Rinisë dhe Sporteve)'' from 2005 to 2013 * Ministry of Culture ''(Ministria e Kulturës)'' from 2013 - ''current''
== Subordinate institutions ==
'''Arts and Culture'''

{{short description|Anti-capitalist, anti-Marxist, and anti-statist ideology}} {{Dablink|This article is specifically about the idea of national-anarchism. See [[Anarchism and nationalism]] for general information about syntheses of nationalist and anarchist ideas.}} {{Nationalism sidebar|Types}} [[File:National-Anarchist star.svg|150px|thumb|National-anarchist star]] [[File:National-Anarchism Movement star.png|thumb|150x150px|National-Anarchist Movement flag]] '''National-anarchism''' is a [[political radicalism|radical]], [[anti-capitalism|anti-capitalist]], [[criticisms of Marxism|anti-Marxist]], and [[anti-statism|anti-statist]] ideology. National-anarchists advocate a [[post-capitalism|post-capitalist]], [[stateless society]] in which communities of different [[ethnic group|ethnic]] or [[race (human categorization)|racial]] groups would be free to develop [[separatism|separately]] in their own autonomous [[Neotribalism|tribal]] [[commune]]s.<ref name="Macklin 2005">{{Harvnb|Macklin|2005}}.</ref><ref name="Sanchez 2009">{{Harvnb|Sanchez|2009}}.</ref> These "[[Permanent autonomous zone|national autonomous zones]]" would be [[Direct democracy|directly democratic]], [[Mutualism (economic theory)|mutualistic]] and [[Self-sustainability|self-sufficient]].
The term ''national-anarchism'' dates back as far as the 1920s.<ref name="Macklin 2005" /> The few scholars who have studied national-anarchism conclude that it represents a further evolution in the thinking of the [[Radical right (Europe)|radical right]] rather than an entirely new dimension.<ref name="Griffin 2003">{{Harvnb|Griffin|2003}}.</ref><ref name=BlackSun>{{Harvnb|Goodrick-Clarke|2003}}.</ref><ref name="Sykes 2005">{{Harvnb|Sykes|2005}}.</ref> National-anarchism has elicited skepticism and outright hostility from both left- and right-wing critics. Some accuse national-anarchists of being [[white nationalism|white nationalists]] who promote [[separatism|ethnic and racial separatism]], while others argue they want the [[Radical chic#Terrorist chic|militant chic]] of calling themselves "anarchists" without the historical and philosophical baggage that accompanies such a claim.<ref name="Sanchez 2009">{{Harvnb|Sanchez|2009}}.</ref><ref name="Sunshine 2008">{{Harvnb|Sunshine|2008}}.</ref>
The '''National-Anarchist Movement'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA--> was propounded since the late 1990s by [[Troy Southgate]].<ref name="Macklin 2005" />
==History== The term ''national-anarchist'' dates back as far as the 1920s, when Helmut Franke, a German conservative revolutionary writer, used it to describe his political stance. However, it would be the writings of other members of the [[Conservative Revolutionary movement|conservative revolutionary movement]], such as [[Ernst Jünger]], which would later provide the philosophical foundation of the contemporary National-Anarchist Movement.<ref name="Macklin 2005" />
In the mid-1990s, [[Troy Southgate]], a former member of the British far-right [[National Front (UK)|National Front]] and founder of the [[International Third Position]], began to move away from [[Strasserism]] and [[distributism|Catholic distributism]] towards [[post-left anarchy|post-left anarchism]] and the [[anarcho-primitivism|primitivist]] [[green anarchism]] articulated in [[Richard Hunt (editor)|Richard Hunt]]'s 1997 book ''To End Poverty: The Starvation of the Periphery by the Core''.<ref name="Macklin 2005" /> However, he fused his anarchist ideology with the [[Julius Evola#Philosophy|radical traditionalism]] of Italian esotericist [[Julius Evola]] and the [[ethnopluralism]] and [[pan-European nationalism]] of [[Nouvelle Droite|French new right]] philosopher [[Alain de Benoist]] to create a newer form of national-anarchism.<ref name="Macklin 2005" />
In 1998, inspired by the concepts of the political soldier and [[leaderless resistance]], Southgate formed the National Revolutionary Faction (NRF) as a [[clandestine cell system]] of [[professional revolutionaries]] conspiring to overthrow the British state.<ref name="Macklin 2005" /> The NRF stressed this was a "highly militant strategy" and advised that some members may only fund the organization.<ref>Quote taken from the [[#CITEREFnrf website strategy|NRF website]]. See {{Harvnb|Macklin|2005}} for a discussion of the NRF's membership structure.</ref> Southgate claims that the NRF took part in anti-[[vivisection]] protests in August 2000 alongside [[Hunt sabotage|hunt saboteurs]] and the [[Animal Liberation Front]] by following a strategy of [[entryism]],<ref name="Macklin 2005" /><ref>{{Harvnb|Goodrick-Clarke|2003|p=50}}</ref> but its only known public action under the "national-anarchist" name was to hold an anarchist heretics fair in October 2000, in which a number of fringe groups participated. However, after a coalition of green anarchists and [[anti-fascism|anti-fascists]] blocked three further events from being held in 2001, Southgate and the NRF abandoned this strategy and retreated to purely disseminating their ideas in [[Internet forum]]s.<ref name="Macklin 2005" /><ref name="Griffin 2003" /> The NRF had long been aware of the bridging power of the Internet, which provided it with a reach and influence hitherto not available to the groupuscular right.<ref>{{Harvnb|Whine|1999}}.</ref> It thus became part of the Euro-American radical right, a virtual community of European and American right-wing extremists seeking to establish a new [[pan-nationalism|pan-national]] and [[ethnoreligious group|ethnoreligious]] identity for all people they believe belong to the "[[Aryan race]]".<ref name="BlackSun" /> Southgate disbanded the NRF in 2003.
Shortly after Southgate and other NRF associates became involved with ''Synthesis'', the online journal of a forum called the ''Cercle de la Rose Noire'', which seeks a fusion of anarchism, [[occultism]] and [[metapolitics]] with the contemporary concerns of the ecological and [[global justice movement]]s. Thus, through the medium of musical subcultures ([[black metal]] and [[neofolk]] music scenes) and the creation of [[permanent autonomous zone]]s for [[neo-völkisch movements|neo-''völkisch'']] communes, they hope to disseminate their [[subversion|subversive]] ideas throughout society in order to achieve [[cultural hegemony]].<ref name="Macklin 2005" />
The national-anarchist idea has spread around the world over the Internet, assisted by groups such as the [[Thule-Seminar]] which set up web sites in the 1990s.<ref>{{Harvnb|Dahl|1999|p=92}}.</ref> In the United States, only a few web sites have been established but there has been a trend towards a steady increase.<ref name="Sunshine 2008" /> National-anarchism in the U.S. began as a relatively obscure movement, made up of probably fewer than 200 individuals, led by Andrew Yeoman of the Bay Area National Anarchists (BANA), based in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], and a couple of other groups in Northern California and Idaho. Organizations based on national-anarchist ideology have gained a foothold in Russia and have been accused of sowing turmoil in the [[environmental movement]] in Germany.<ref name="Sanchez 2009" /> There are adherents in England, Spain and Australia, among other nations.<ref name="Sanchez 2009" />
On 8 September 2007 in Sydney, Australia, the [[anti-globalization movement]] mobilized against [[neoliberalism|neoliberal economic policies]] by opposing the [[Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation]] summit. During the street protests, national-anarchists infiltrated the left-anarchist [[black bloc]] but the police had to protect them from being expelled by irate activists.<ref name="Sanchez 2009" /><ref>[[#CITEREFMercerChesterton2007|''The Sunday Telegraph'', September 9, 2007]]."[Some protest groups] seemed thankful for the strong police presence. Twenty members of an anarchist movement, all wearing black hoodies with their faces covered by bandanas, were escorted away by police after marching only 20m. The group, New Right Australia and New Zealand, became a focal point for the crowd, who turned on them, accusing them of being Nazis."</ref> Since then, national-anarchists have joined other marches in Australia and in the U.S.; in April 2008, they protested on behalf of the [[Tibetan independence movement]] against the Chinese government during the [[2008 Summer Olympics torch relay#International leg|Olympic torch relay in both Canberra, Australia, and San Francisco]].<ref name="Sunshine 2008" /> National-anarchists in the U.S. are carefully studying the successes and failures of their more prominent international counterparts as they attempt to similarly win converts from the [[radical environmentalism|radical environmentalist]] and [[white nationalism|white nationalist]] movements in the U.S.<ref name="Sanchez 2009" />
On [[May Day]] 2010, BANA participated in the Golden Gate [[Minuteman Project|Minutemen]]'s march in front of San Francisco City Hall in support of [[Arizona SB 1070|Arizona's anti-illegal immigration senate bill]]. The march took place during [[International Workers' Day]] demonstrations as an attempt to counter mass protest against the bill, in [[Mission District, San Francisco|San Francisco's Mission District]]. Local news media reported that Yeoman and four other national-anarchists were physically assaulted by about 10 protesters as they left the march.<ref>[[#CITEREFSmiley2010|''SF Weekly'', May 1, 2010]]; [[#CITEREFGulezianHollyfied2010|KGO-TV report, May 1, 2010]].</ref>
==Ideology== The [[Conservative Revolutionary movement|conservative revolutionary]] concept of the [[Anarch (sovereign individual)|anarch]], as articulated by [[Ernst Jünger|Jünger]], is central to national-anarchism.<ref name="Macklin 2005" /> National-anarchists see [[modernity]], [[liberalism]], [[materialism]], [[consumerism]], [[immigration]], [[multiracialism]], [[multiculturalism]], and [[globalization]] as the primary causes of the social decline of [[nation]]s and [[cultural identity]].<ref name="Macklin 2005" /> They stress a strategic and ideological alliance of [[separatism#Racial|racial separatists]] in the [[Western world]], [[Eurasianists#Eurasianism today|neo-Eurasianists]] in Russia, [[islamism|Islamists]] in [[Muslim world|Muslim-majority countries]], [[list of active autonomist and secessionist movements|autonomist and secessionist movements]] in the [[least developed country|least developed countries]], and [[anti-Zionism|anti-Zionists]] everywhere to resist the "[[New World Order (conspiracy theory)|New World Order]]"—globalization viewed as an instrument of [[List of conspiracy theories#Jewish conspiracy theories|Jewish-dominated international banking]] and [[American imperialism]]—that is inevitably leading to global [[economic collapse]] and [[ecological collapse]].<ref name="Macklin 2005" /><ref name="Sunshine 2008" />
National-anarchism echoes most [[anarchist schools of thought|strains of anarchism]] by expressing a desire to reorganize human relationships, with an emphasis on replacing the hierarchical structures of the state and capitalism with [[localism (politics)|local]], community [[Anarchist law#Decision-making|decision-making]]. National-anarchists, however, aim towards a [[decentralization|decentralized]] social order where each [[neotribalism|new tribe]] builds and maintains a [[permanent autonomous zone]] for a [[self-sufficiency|self-sufficient]] [[commune]], which is politically [[Direct democracy|directly democratic]], economically [[mutualism (economic theory)|mutualistic]], socially and culturally [[traditional values|traditional]], and ecologically [[sustainability|sustainable]].<ref name="Macklin 2005" />
Asserting the [[right to difference]], national-anarchists publicly advocate a model of society in which communities that wish to can practice racial, ethnic, religious or sexual [[separatism]] are able to peacefully coexist alongside mixed or integrated communities without requiring force.<ref name=ARV>{{Harvnb|Preston|2003}}.</ref> They claim that "[[permanent autonomous zone|national autonomous zones]]" (NAZs) could exist with their own rules for permanent residence without the strict ethnic divisions and violence advocated by other forms of "[[blood and soil]]" [[ethnic nationalism]].<ref name=ARV />
Many national-anarchists are influenced by the [[perennial philosophy]] of [[Julius Evola|Evola]] and the radical [[traditionalist school]], which calls for a "[[Revolt Against the Modern World|revolt against the modern world]]".<ref name="Sanchez 2009" /> They therefore have a pessimistic vision of modern [[Western culture]] yet optimistically believe that the "[[The Decline of the West|decline of the West]]" will pave the way for its materialism to be expunged and replaced by the [[idealism]] of [[The Primordial Tradition|primordial tradition]].<ref name="Macklin 2005" /> Many national-anarchists reject [[Christianity]] because they believe it is a [[Abrahamic religions|Semitic religion]] that usurped the [[Aryan race|Aryan]] legacy of [[Mithraic mysteries]] as the historically dominant religion and moral system of the West.<ref name="Macklin 2005" /> Some embrace a [[anarchism and religion#Religious anarchism and anarchist themes in religions|spiritual anarchism]] based on different forms of [[neopaganism]], [[occultism]] and [[ethnic religion|ethnic mysticism]], especially [[neo-völkisch movements#Nordic racial paganism|Nordic racial paganism]], which they view as genuine expressions of Western spirituality, culture and identity that can also serve as an antidote to the [[social alienation|socially alienating]] effects of [[consumer culture]]. Other national-anarchists hold [[racial segregation]] and [[revitalization movement|cultural revitalization]] through the establishment of [[confederation]]s of autonomous tribal [[commune]]s ("[[Volk (German word)|''volk'']] autonomy") as the ultimate barrier against globalized racial and [[cultural homogenization]].<ref name="Macklin 2005" />
According to American [[panarchism|panarchist]] Keith Preston, national-anarchism and classical American ideals of [[Jeffersonian democracy]] are reconcilable, despite the [[anti-Americanism]] of European national-anarchists and the patriotism of American [[paleoconservatism|paleoconservatives]], because of their common values: [[regionalism (politics)|regionalism]], [[localism (politics)|localism]], [[agrarianism]], and [[traditional values|traditionalism]].<ref name=ARV />
==Position on political spectrum== While the combination of post-left anarchist opposition to [[statism]] and [[capitalism]], with [[ethnopluralism|right-wing support for ethnic and racial separatism]], makes its classification on the left-right political spectrum problematic, the following scholars who have examined national-anarchism consider it to be on the radical right.<ref name="Macklin 2005" /><ref name="Griffin 2003">{{Harvnb|Griffin|2003}}.</ref><ref name="Sykes 2005" /><ref name="Sunshine 2008" />
In 2003, [[Roger Griffin]] argued that national-anarchism is a segment of the groupuscular right which has evolved towards a "mazeway resynthesis" between "classic fascism, third positionism, neo-anarchism and new types of anti-systemic politics born of the anti-globalization movement", whose main ideological innovation is a [[stateless society|stateless]] [[palingenetic ultranationalism]].<ref name="Griffin 2003" />
In 2005, Graham D. Macklin, in his essay ''Co-opting the counter culture: Troy Southgate and the National Revolutionary Faction'', building off of the writings of Griffin, argued that the [[conservative revolutionary]] concept of the [[Anarch (sovereign individual)|anarch]] provides sanction for the ideological shapeshifting and unrestrained [[eclecticism]] of national-anarchism, allowing its adherents to assert they have transcended the dichotomy of conventional politics to embrace higher political forms that are "beyond left and right".<ref name="Macklin 2005" /> Macklin further argued that despite a protean capacity for change, [[far right|far-right]] groupuscules retain some principes which he calls core fascist values (namely [[palingenesis]], [[ultranationalism]], [[anti-liberal]] and [[Criticisms of Marxism|anti-Marxist]] third positionism, and violent [[direct action]]). Macklin therefore concludes that national-anarchism is a synthesis of anarchism and fascism (or, more precisely, the [[Julius Evola#Politics|radical traditionalism]] of [[Julius Evola|Evola]]), which represents a "[[Revolt Against the Modern World|revolt against the modern world]]".<ref name="Macklin 2005" />
In 2005, Alan Sykes, in his book ''The Radical Right in Britain: Social Imperialism to the BNP'', argued that national-anarchism represents a further evolution in the thinking of the radical right rather than an entirely new dimension, a response to the new situation of the late 20th century in which the apparent triumph of [[materialism|materialist]] capitalism on a global scale requires a greater assertion of the centrality of [[idealism|anti-materialist]] nationalism.<ref name="Sykes 2005" />
==Criticism== National-anarchism has critics on both the [[left–right politics|left and right of the political spectrum]]. Both left- and right-wing critics look upon their politics with skepticism, if not outright hostility, in part because they find it difficult to consolidate national-anarchism into the traditional right-left spectrum.
Left-wing critics assert that national-anarchism is a "Trojan horse for white nationalism" and represents what many [[anti-fascism|anti-fascists]] see as the potential new face of [[fascism]]. They argue that it is a form of [[crypto-fascism]] which hopes to avoid the stigma of classic fascism by [[cultural appropriation|appropriating]] symbols, slogans, and stances of the [[left anarchism|left-wing anarchist]] movement, while engaging in [[entryism]] to inject some core [[Fascism#Tenets|fascist values]] into the [[anti-globalization movement|anti-globalization]] and [[environmental movement|environmental]] movements. They further argue that national-anarchists hope to draw members away from traditional white nationalist groups to their own synthesis of ideas, which they claim are "neither left nor right". These critics warn that the danger national-anarchists represent is not in their marginal political strength, but in their potential to show an innovative way that [[neo-fascism|neo-fascist]] groups can rebrand themselves and reset their project on a new footing. Even if the results are modest, this can disrupt left-wing social movements and their focus on [[egalitarianism]] and [[social justice]]; and instead spread [[separatism|separatist]] ideas based on [[naturalistic fallacy]], [[racism]], [[antisemitism]], [[heterosexism]], and [[antifeminism]] amongst grassroots activists.<ref name="Sunshine 2008" />
Some far-right critics argue that [[neo-Nazism|neo-Nazis]] joining the National-Anarchist Movement will lead to them losing credit for the successes of their "[[anti-Zionism|anti-Zionist]]" struggle if it is co-opted by [[left anarchism|left-wing anarchists]]. They further argue that national-anarchists want the [[Radical chic#Terrorist chic|militant chic]] of calling themselves "anarchists" without the historical and philosophical baggage that accompanies such a claim, such as the link with 19th-century [[Jewish anarchism|Jewish anarchists]].<ref name="Sanchez 2009" />

Constitution of India doesn't define the word 'Minority' but has used the word minorities considering two attributes religion or language of a person. For minorities Constitution of India has envisaged a number of rights and safeguards. To provide enough equality and to dwindle the discrimination, makers have spelt out various things in Fundamental Rights (PartIII); Directive Principles of State policy (Part IV) and also the Fundamental Duties (Part IV-A). However, with rising right and rising wedge between right and left and also the ephemeral political aspirations of various political parties have diluted the discrimination safeguards.
The Union Government set up the '''National Commission for Minorities''' (NCM) under the National Commission for Minorities Act, 1992. Six religious communities, viz; Muslims, Christians, Sikhs, Buddhists, Zoroastrians (Parsis) and Jains have been notified in Gazette of India as minority communities by the Union Government all over India .<ref>{{cite web |url=http://minorities.in/profiles.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131025054311/http://www.minorities.in/profiles.php |archivedate=25 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Original notification of 1993 was for Five religious communities Sikhs, Buddhists,Parsis,Christians and Muslims.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://egazette.nic.in/WriteReadData/1993/E-0462-1993-0633-18514.pdf|title=Extra ordinary Gazette Notification|last=|first=|date=23 October 1993|website=Egazzette|publisher=GOI|access-date=10 October 2016}}</ref>
== UN Declaration == The NCM adheres to the [[United Nations]] Declaration of 18 December 1992 which states that "States shall protect the existence of the National or Ethnic, Cultural, Religious and Linguistic identity of minorities within their respective territories and encourage conditions for the promotion of that identity.” <ref>http://ncm.nic.in/un_declaration.html</ref>
==Functions and Powers==
The Commission has the following functions:<ref>{{cite web|title=National Commission for Minorities (Amendment) Act 1995|url=http://www.ncm.nic.in/ncm_act.html#c1|website=http://www.ncm.nic.in/|publisher=Government of India|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref>
# Evaluate the progress of the development of Minorities under the Union and States. # Monitor the working of the safeguards provided in the Constitution and in laws enacted by Parliament and the State Legislatures. # Make recommendations for the effective implementation of safeguards for the protection of the interests of Minorities by the Central Government or the State Governments. # Look into specific complaints regarding deprivation of rights and safeguards of the Minorities and take up such matters with the appropriate authorities. # Cause studies to be undertaken into problems arising out of any discrimination against Minorities and recommend measures for their removal. # Conduct studies, research and analysis on the issues relating to socio-economic and educational development of Minorities. # Suggest appropriate measures in respect of any Minority to be undertaken by the Central Government or the State Governments. # Make periodical or special reports to the Central Government on any matter pertaining to Minorities and in particular the difficulties confronted by them. # Any other matter which may be referred to it by the Central Government.
The Commission has the following powers:
* Summoning and enforcing the attendance of any person from any part of India and examining him on oath. * Requiring the discovery and production of any document. * Receiving evidence on affidavit. * Requisitioning any public record or copy thereof from any court or office. * Issuing commissions for the ex
== Composition of Commission == The act states<ref>http://ncm.nic.in/Composition_of_Commission.html</ref> that the Commission shall consist of: * a Chairperson, * a Vice Chairperson and * Five Members to be nominated by the Central Government from amongst persons of eminence, ability and integrity; provided that five members including the Chairperson shall be from amongst the minority communities.
==Rights & Safeguards of Minorities<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ncm.nic.in/Constitutional_provisions.html|title=Constitutional Provisions|last=|first=|date=|website=National Commission for Minorities|publisher=GOI|access-date=10 October 2016}}</ref>== Although Indian Constitution does not define word Minority but it has provided constitutional safeguards and fundamental rights to minorities:
=== Under Fundamental Rights Part III of Indian Constitution === Indian state is committed to administer these rights which can be enforced by judiciary # Right of ‘any section of the citizens’ to ‘conserve’ its ‘distinct language, script or culture’; [Article 29(1)] # Right of all Religious and Linguistic Minorities to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice;[Article 30(1)] # Freedom of Minority-managed educational institutions from discrimination in the matter of receiving aid from the State;[Article30(2)]
=== Under Part XVII Official Language of Indian Constitution === # Rights for any section of population for language spoken by them ;[Article 347] # Provision for facilities of instruction in mother tongue ; [Article 350A] # Provisioning a special officer for linguistic minorities and defining his duties ; [ Article 350B]
== Sachar Committee Report == On March 9, 2005 the then Prime Minister issued a Notification for the constitution of a High Level Committee to prepare a report on the social, economic and educational status of the Muslim community of India. Recommendations contained in the Report of the High Level Committee on Social, Economic and Educational Status of the Muslim Community of India headed by Justice Rajindar Sachar (Retd.): # Need for Transparency, Monitoring and Data Availability - Create a National Data Bank (NDB) where all relevant data for various socio-religious categories are maintained. # Enhancing the Legal Basis for Providing Equal Opportunities Set up an Equal Opportunity Commission to look into grievances of deprived groups like minorities. # Shared Spaces: Need to Enhance Diversity: The idea of providing certain incentives to a 'diversity index' should be explored. # Education: a process of evaluating the content of the school text books needs to be initiated to purge them of explicit and implicit content that may impart inappropriate social values, especially religious intolerance. Need to ensure that all children in the age group 0-14 have access to free and high quality education. # High quality Government schools should be set up in all areas of Muslim concentration. Exclusive schools for girls should be set up, particularly for the 9-12 standards. This would facilitate higher participation of Muslim girls in school education. In co-education schools more women teachers need to be appointed. # Provide primary education in Urdu in areas where Urdu speaking population is concentrated. # Mechanisms to link madarsas with higher secondary school board. # Recognise degrees from madarsas for eligibility in Defence Services, Civil Services and Banking examinations. # Increase employment share of Muslims, particularly where there is great deal of public dealing. # Enhancing Participation in Governance: appropriate state level laws can be enacted to ensure minority representation in local bodies # Create a nomination procedure to increase participation of minorities in public bodies. # Establish a delimitation procedure that does not reserve constituencies with high minority population for SCs. # Enhancing Access to Credit and Government Programmes: Provide financial and other support to initiatives built around occupations where Muslims are concentrated and that have growth potential. # Improve participation and share of minorities, particularly Muslims, in business of regular commercial banks # Improving Employment Opportunities and Conditions The Committee suggested that policies should “sharply focus on inclusive development and ‘mainstreaming’ of the Community while respecting diversity.”<ref>http://www.minorityaffairs.gov.in/sites/upload_files/moma/files/Sachar%20Committee%20Recommendations-English.pdf</ref>
